2sorrUKTA1fdDdUN8Tbihg.text: I do love the Duck & Waffle. Every time I have been I discover more on the menu I love, staff that are friendly and smiling, drinks that are delicious, and a view to rival the best. Brilliant at breakfasts, and a good place to see a view of London as a whole, to a romantic dinner (just make sure your partner is not afraid of heights) you will throughly enjoy this place. I know I do.

yx-I3oTsbh-ksOFGxw6QiA.text: This place was all over social media so I made sure I went to check it out while in London. Loved the lift ride up to the 40th Floor, it's glass which means an incredible view! We entered through a trendy bar to the main restaurant where we were lucky to be seated near the window. Of course, we ordered the signature dish and enjoyed it! It is a unique combination that absolutely works. Recommend a visit!

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Crispy Confit Leg, Duck Egg with Mustard Maple Syrup

WCIh-Cz785CI1BLqy9bVoQ.text: This place is super fancy and exclusive and, above all, delicious. It's a tapas style place or has larger dishes to share. But your waiter will explain it all to you. Get the bacon wrapped dates and the ox cheek donut and the lentil thing... Forget the exact name. It's expensive but delicious and the view cannot be beat.

7ZhzR8_fTBukzwSSlnTy9w.text: Delicious. But you go for the views. Absolutely worth the overpriced food & drink

WSMSTnYjISLbbvaGd6LzFw.text: Do try the duck and waffle, even if it is breakfast time!

80LdlWBpfbcnm1SaTwxwOw.text: Phenomenal dining experience in London. The chicken was a hearty and savory dinner that we split between two people. We saw a rainbow during our meal - food and ambiance made for a perfect first night in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. The view and a delicious lemon meringue dessert.
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

ZWH2YPfo8xk89mTWhQeIRw.text: Horrible. The door woman was incredibly rude. We were in a taxi for 45 mins. Two nights in London and the worst place you could imagine. It's open 24 hours so you'd expect after midnight you were a little happy coming from dinner and drinks. There were three of us and were laughing but I guess that meant we were too inebriated to be allowed in. Never in my entire life has that happened. Not NY, SF, LA ,Paris etc etc etc. And I'm not in my twenties. Jennifer at the door was so wrong and rude. After 30 mins in an Uber and having a great night with friends, she ruined it.

YBV0XIEK-9V2Y3rvJ_AV4Q.text: 24hr breakfast, what more can you want. Great for that after club chillout.

c6TDwBdYpFe60lJDU79zvQ.text: Wonderful food and stunning views. Great place to go to celebrate something special. Worth trying to book a couple of months in advance as it's hard to get a reservation.Try and get a table during sunset to watch London skyline go from day to night!I loved everything on the small plates menu but wasn't too impressed with the duck and waffle signature dish. I would recommend get lots of dishes on the small plates, the bacon wrapped dates off the classics section and a couple of the bread dishes.

E5oWZARaHhFyqCzEkOMoxw.text: The view in incredible, and the food yummy. Lovely place for a romantic dinner, you can go any hour of the day!!

HbCSVqS_a-6aek7RvuJFXQ.text: This is one of my favorite restaurants here! The views are spectacular, make sure you sit by the window.

o9m6sBal3s176jioNUlmSg.text: The view is not worth it. Don't spend hundreds of pounds on awful food and poor service. We had lukewarm ox cheeks that had no flavor whatsoever served with root vegetables that were under cooked and tasteless. All this was served atop a bed of heavy and poorly cooked barley. The dessert was a foamy bizarre mess.  The only nice thing was the one thing over which they had no control...the tiny slice of Stilton.  Even the cocktails were bad. The D and W is deeply depressing if you care at all about food and even more so if you care about getting value for your money. There are so many great restaurants in London...don't go here.

h3We2mk3JmROyFqJQjzqxQ.text: The food was very nice, although it was very, very expensive - Expensive but worth it. The dishes were unique and of a very good quality of ingredients. The location was very nice - ask for a window seat. The staff were friendly, for the most part, and all very well informed. (Sadly, someone had their crying baby out with them for Sunday brunch, and that was painful, but not the fault of the Duck & Waffle! It is all windows, so all glass, so the crying was one huge eco. I wish they had a rule against having babies in such a sophisticated, expensive environment. I really do not want to hear a crying baby all through a brunch splurge!)

yutROK27UdHK9ZIKuSsOyg.text: All sorts of winning. Yes, it is expensive, but the ratio of price:winning is very good compared to lots of places in London. We showed up wanting dinner around 11pm on a Wednesday, with no reservation. Doorman said "Fully booked, but there's a pub down the street that I think is still serving burgers." I said, "Not interested in burgers. Interested in oysters. Anything we can do?" And things were done. We ended up with a fantastic table by the window looking out over Tower Bridge and the river. Started out with mixed oysters and smoked eel. Oysters were delicious - properly shucked, lots of liquor. Paired brilliantly with the cocktail I had, the "Mind Your Ps and Qs," basically a G and T infused with sweet pea and hopped up on mint. Eels won on multiple fronts - packed with umami and elevated our bottle of Bordeaux. For mains, we had duck and waffle and ribeye. Ribeye was cooked perfectly - we ordered "rare" and got what would be considered a perfect medium rare Stateside (British beef temperatures are a step hotter than those in the U.S., so a note to my fellow Americans - if you want your steak medium rare here in Londontown, order it RARE!). Marrow bone made it even more delicious. As for the duck and waffle, its virtues have already been covered very well here. Basically, delicious. The wine list seems to focus on famous labels, which would make sense for a 24-hour place in the City, where bankers can take clients to impress them. Many of the wines at the "low" end are priced aggressively - a Prodductori Barbaresco for over £70 that would sell for around 30 Euros in a restaurant in Italy (I've had that wine in a restaurant in Alba for about that and have purchased retail for 15 Euros - it is a very good wine but NOT worth £70). They did have some high-end Sassicaia and first-growth Bordeauxes that were priced competitively - again, great for City people, but above my price range on this particular occasion. We had a nice Medoc for around £80 that sort of underdelivered but paired pleasantly with our dinner. Post-dinner, my husband had a glass of the Cotes du Rhone that was on the list for under £50 per bottle that actually over-delivered and probably next time, we'll go for a bottle of that.Cocktails are fantastic. We had too many - for sure above our allotted number of "UK Units" of alcohol. I have no complaints about any of the myriad ones we tried, so I suggest trying whatever fits your personal taste.In all, a winning restaurant.

_KuI0c5FOHPfDVhegLe4Vg.text: I heard mixed things about this place but wanted to check it out... I mean, having a duck on a waffle with maple syrup, it's too intriguing not to! I was very lucky to have gotten a booking a few days before the date of choice, because I heard you have to wait at least a month for a good table. Unfortunately one of the lifts was broken, which was the only downside to the experience because being in that lift is pretty amazing. It's completely clear so the view takes your breath away. But this time it was really crowded so didn't get to appreciate the view as much as I could have otherwise. You go to the 40th floor and the staff immediately takes care of you. There's a small bar before the restaurant space but we had a late dinner booking so we went straight to the table to order drinks, which were fabulous. The tables closest to the windows are obviously the best, but unfortunately we were seated close to the kitchen which was farthest away from the view. I didn't mind it though, I enjoyed staring at all the dishes come out.The appetizers are stunning. The garlic bread is a must-have... I've never had garlic bread so deliciously original. Hands-down the best bread I had in my life actually. Soft cloves of garlic nested in the soft bread but wasn't overpowering. The octopus was also really nice with the roasted potatoes, and the doughnut was really interesting! I didn't enjoy the raw scallops though... each piece was way too small and was the most disappointing dish of the evening. Of course, then comes the duck & waffle, and I absolutely loved it! The whole combination worked perfectly together. I poured all the maple syrup over the duck and egg and inhaled the dish. The portion could be bigger. Overall, I can't wait to bring my siblings here, it will really impress them :)

ig_O-siuQPmCw8c0JxCFZA.text: This was definitely one of the best dining experiences I've ever had. Must orders: ox cheek donut, lamb, pain perdu. Service was excellent, cocktails were delicious, views are incredible. Plus the whole thing was less money than I was expecting. If you're willing to go at a weird time you can get a reservation a bit faster. I'd recommend planning about a month in advance.

ZskldXr-GjhaQ8fZOhExng.text: My friend kept boasting how good this place was, she kept going on and on but now it's my turn. it was awesomeee! not to mention you get the full city view up on this 40th floor and especially when dining at night, city lights+ candle lit = the ultimate romantic dining. You must order their duck and waffle menu because it's obviously their signature dish! I was curious at first since the menu was mixing the saltiness (from the duck) and sweetness (from waffle) together but as soon as i had my first bite on it, I knew this was the one. They managed to combine the crispyness of the duck with the spongy texture of the waffle perfectly, the maple syrup and duck egg were the best add-ons to the dish. Everything just worked together perfectly and their was no room for error. Also, my first time ever trying the foie gras here and they matched it with toast and nutella! Not just that, for desserts I had mars bars chocolate but DEEP FRIED ! first time ever and believe me I'm already thinking of going back to dip my chocolate bars in the pan haha. i know it sounds sooo fatty but its always fair enough to treat yourself once in while. Like they said, desserts is stressed spelt backwards ;)

sFoZDvjfpY65unKdGwtzhQ.text: The view is absolutely amazing, which is just as well because if not for the view, they should burn it down and claim on the insurance. Since they're on the 40th floor, there would be collateral damage. We went there for a birthday breakfast that we made a booking for a week ago. When we got there, they had no record of the booking, despite showing them a copy of the email they sent confirming it and noting that it was for a birthday. The hostess / waitress who seated us was really helpful despite no record of the booking and while she was still on shift, service was good. Once she left though, service went downhill fast. We ordered a coffee and an orange juice at one point. The coffee arrived but 15 minutes later there was still no orange juice. Getting the waiter's attention to fix this took ages. Getting that waiter's attention for anything took ages, so we eventually left without the second course we wanted.The food was ok. The menu at 06:00 is pretty limited, but that's expected for a place like this. One meal was good, the other was ok. The egg was overdone to the point that you could bounce it, but I guess that's a small issue in the grand scheme of things. The icing on the cake though was the crust on the vomit that I stepped in when I went to the men's room. I'm not sure how long it takes for vomit to get crusty, but I'm sure it's longer than the gap between bathroom checks for an establishment like this should be. All in all, a very disappointing visit and a bad start to a day of celebration.

tpFT4Vz6cwXU401x0RyEKg.text: One of the coolest restaurants I have been to in London. Right near the Liverpool tube stop, you must take a very cool life up forty stories to reach the place. (Note, Sushisamba is on the 38th floor; if you want an exquisite view rather than a middling one, continue riding up!). From our corner of the restaurant, we could make out both the dome of Wembley and the Olympic Village. I ordered the eponymous duck and waffle (which also comes with a sunny side up duck egg and mustard maple syrup). What a combination. The taste was unexpectedly wonderful. The "Rosemary and Garlic" is a bread-like appetizer that you really must try. We also got strips of pigs' ears for the table, which were great as a novelty. Speaking of novel tea, I had a fresh mint tea to end the meal--it was a great way to drag out the lunch and enjoy the sunset of London (which probably would have been awesome were it not for the clouds)!

Ebn2Aw6vHMLeccAwkTF6HQ.text: Had to book 2 months in advance for a peak-time Sunday brunch. Colombian omelette was juicy and had full flavour of fresh avocado. Their coffee was just slightly above average but the Belgian waffle with a grilled banana and homemade Nutella was real goodness. It is the highest restaurant in London (that's why they say on their website) and the view looked even better in the private dining area.

Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Belgian Waffle with grilled banana, vanilla icecream and home-made nutella

qthWQTZNvHWPVcO3ank2dA.text: Seriously? Is everyone else at a different restaurant? Service was appalling; waitress needed summoning 20 minutes after being seated, who then stood by the table in silence - hint: a 'hello' would be nice! Mimosas were flat. Not a word was said - seriously - until she handed back my credit card with a terse 'thanks'.On the plus side, the duck and waffle dish is nice, and the view is great. Get it together and stop resting on your location to pull in the crowds.

1xf_QyXaJhaJKqKrUTFfYg.text: A bit disappointed to be honest.  Enjoyed some of the dishes but most were just too sweet.  Their signature dish "duck and waffle" was surprisingly predictable and my duck was dried out.  Good cocktails at the bar though.  And of course the views are pretty spectactular.

h1EEHZaPz5Md5R4IkwPOkQ.text: Besides the view, which is superb, the restaurant leaves a lot to be desired. Overstaffed and bureaucratic with a rustic decor that makes no sense for the ultra modern building it is in...the 24h operation is commendable and the drinks seemed decent, but it failed to surpass a mere tourist attraction.

EECLS_u_6rIoynCR_7j6_A.text: Get the "Foie gras All Day" which is toast with foie gras, bacon, Nutella, a sunny-side up quail egg and some fried blood pudding. Insane and incredible. Also, you can't beat the view.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Foie Gras All Day

6ujxSK2rhH02jyF-020__Q.text: Outstanding.  How lucky we were to find this spot open for breakfast at 6am.  Views are world class.  Decor is edgy and sharp. Food was excellent.  Service on point.  If you're visiting London you won't be disappointed here.

NGXHdVC72HbnZ6E54_ziPA.text: I don't really have anything bad to say about Duck & Waffle. The view is breathtaking. The food is good and very creative- the menu changes monthly so expect to constantly be surprised with interesting dishes. The price is good- a lot less than you would expect. And the best thing about Duck & Waffle? It is open 24/7- a perfect place to watch the sunrise while having brunch after a long night out.

GuUiUlHL2l7YCXethcvjRg.text: Duck and Waffle? It is, to  be brief - totally amazing. I hadn't even finished dessert before I had booked to come back twice more - in the same week. Yes, it was that good. Once you've got past the slightly overenthusiastic security on the front door - you enter an express glass lift which whisks you on an ear-popping journey up to the 40th floor. And the views - astonishing. The moment you get past the wierd 'inside out' bar (its in the middle of the room and you have to sort of mill around it) the restaurant opens up to a 360 degree vista of London. Or a vista of, well, Essex, if you're sitting on the wrong side. We, however, were ushered into the best table in the place by the amazingly helpful Gavin, looking right down on the top of the Gherkin and further down onto Tower Bridge and the Tower of London, the lights of Commercial Street snaking away to our left. And the food? Gorgeous. A couple of starters - peas in the pod with a scattering of bacon and a note of sticky eucalyptus. Cod tongues (more likely cheeks) in breadcrumbs with a chunky tartare sauce , bound in a twist of newspaper. For the main course, we shared a delicious rabbit rillettes with beer chutney and flatbread, a fantastic roasted beetroot and goats curd - and of course, the eponymous duck and waffle, a confit leg on top of two chunks of waffle, topped by a fried duck egg and some mustard maple syrup on the side. I neither like duck nor waffles, nor even fried eggs - yet I loved it. Pudding - of course - had to be the chocolate brownie with peanut butter ice cream and melted marshmallow. Let me say that again. Chocolate brownie with peanut butter ice cream and melted marshmallow. The bill - a shade over twenty pounds each. All this with that incredible view, from dusk to night time and the lights of London twinkling far below. Only two more visits? Not enough. Not nearly enough.

3E4fGS7hnxxOmxlQcxdNZw.text: the view, the view, the view. very special. staring down on the gherkin is pretty amazing. as its the view of st pauls and tower bridge.the food, the food, the food. very different, very reasonable and very very tasty. try the scallops on the salt block, the duck and waffle and the foie gras chocolate black pudding.the service, the service. pretty good overall. pleasant and attentive.the kitchen. sort out the ventilation. unacceptable to have fumes pouring into the dining hall.the drinks. the big downfall. way overpriced. cheapest decent white is £35. cocktails a minimum of £10. four of us had a £210 bill, £120 was drinks (2 bottles of wine and 4 cocktails). we were stuffed. you figure it out. i would totally recommend however. just for the view. also never felt rushed - dunno about the 24/7 thing tho because UK diners aren't really used to that, be interesting to see who is in there post 2am, or who isn't off their face.

tjVlRs6Y2eI1hTqwj-J2Vg.text: Genuine thoughts.I arrived for breakfast on the 16th september with a friend with much expectation about this place. Unfortunately, at best I'd give this a very average rating and I would not be able to, in good faith, recommend this place to anyone1) Service - after asking what the best thing on the menu was I was told everything is great and nothing was worthy of being recommended/standing. out. The gentlemen serving me seemed to be very curt, unfriendly and did not even seem to care about making suggestions based on what I would like. This was truly disappointing.2) The view - a very good view of London from the Heron tower and a wide selection of drinks may mean this is a better place to go for drinks versus food3) The food (and drink) - I cannot believe these people served me what could only be described as "spinach in boiled water" which was supposed to be earl grey tea. I have not got high expectations regarding this but since this arrived before my meal it almost tempted me to get up and leave. Extremely disappointed.Fortunately, the steak and eggs benedict was very nice and a very different combination to the usual salmon or ham. I do recommend this is you are in town for breakfast but I cannot recommend the full breakfast which my friend found truly disappointing.Overall 3 stars, come for the view but not the food.

C-b2dce6XFe0kWJen_HTKA.text: I've had the pleasure of eating here a number of times now and each occasion has been, well, a pleasure!Whilst I love food, I also enjoy the whole experience of eating out and believe the surroundings and service of an establishment are equally important as the food with the proviso that they should also be 'appropriate' for the experience. For example, when in a chain restaurant found in abundance on high streets everywhere, I accept I'm going to receive an anodyne service from a young person, whose enquiry about whether my meal is ok is a repetitively drilled out line borne from corporate training rather than of genuine concern that my ketchup was too runny.The thing is, I really don't mind. It's expected for that type of experience and therefore, anything over and above that expectation is going to get a thumbs up from me, whether it's a Nando's or Michelin experience.Now, my expectation of the D&W was as sky high as the place itself. Having read reviews in the broadsheets about how fabulous and unpretentious the place was, how good the food was, how it's where most working chefs go to relax and eat after finishing their shifts (D&W is a 24hr a day affair) I was almost ready to be disappointed. However, this place excels on all counts. Food - excellent, service - charming and attentive without being intrusive, surroundings - hard pressed to find anything better in London. The food is reasonably priced and less than I expected. The booze is more but probably a reflection of being in the City - I can imagine some suits wouldn't balk at paying a few hundred quid for a bottle of sparkles. Having said that, it was great to see local beer and English wine on the list too, supporting local concerns is also a passion of mine - we had a bottle of English sparkly, that was delicious and worth the cash. You will need to book in advance but do it online, it's not difficult. You can view the menu online too, it all adds to the build up and excitement of going and it's a great experience.

pJP8P3N9Ks3ZZWKKo5tX_g.text: I was excited to try this restaurant and it was on top of my list, but their famous duck and waffle is over hyped! There is nothing special and unique about it. The duck was tender, but it was missing some flavor. I also did not like the spicy ox cheek doughnut. The jam over powered the whole entire dish. I did really enjoy the foie gras creme brûlée, smoked eel, and crispy polenta. I would definitely order those two things again, if I decide to come back! You're basically paying for the elevator ride to the 40th floor and the gorgeous views. The service is also outstanding. Our waiter was very attentive and the whole staff were friendly. It is a great experience to try it once, and enjoy the views and ambiance. Just don't come here with high expectations for their food! Overall, I give it a 3.5 because of the fantastic service and stunning view.

Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

nF7JMDOaDQYjqU49XXOfAg.text: In London for the night. Went out for some drinks with some friends and planned to end the night here. We get there after 3:30AM. Get denied entry because I wasn't dressed "Casual Elegance." It's 3:30am. Dude at the front desk told me my "ripped trousers" wasn't going to cut it and didn't meet the dress code requirement. 1 min later a group of guys walk out and 2 out of 4 had "ripped trousers."

b7Teo9OUH15WExkogQ8Z5w.text: Hyper hip popular spot for fun party atmosphere but not as much for food.Food: 2.5, Atmosphere: 4, Service: 3Cost to worth it rating: 4 (lot of food)Return worthiness: noHighlights:- Vibe: energetic and lively. Very Las Vegas style scene.- Atmosphere: on the 40th floor via elevator though not much of a view on typical London cloudy days- Risotto balls: crispy bites with a creamy center. 4 stars - Chocolate dessert orb: impressive presentation pouring hot liquid over the hollow chocolate shell and my friends all loved it. 4 stars- Fish: simple fish cooked well but didn't need the mayo. 3.5 stars- Burrata ravioli: rich large pasta pieces filled with cheese. 3.25 stars Midlights:- Duck and waffle: namesake dish which is a play off of the American chicken and waffle upscaled. Actual duck is fine with a spiced fried batter but waffle was dry and didn't care for the mustard maple syrup. 3 stars - Octupus: tender and flavorful under the sauce though there was a lot of sauce. 3 starsLowlights:- Chile gruyere bread: chile was far too spicy and cheese very greasy. Bread didn't come cut and was hard to cut. 2.5 stars - Pavlova: way too sweet, custard was a weird liquidy texture, and meringue was too hard. Rhubarb sherbert was the best part.- Selection: most everything had cream or mayo or mustard on it. Popular spot but was disappointed by the food and there are much better places to eat in London.

AQvIpIkkOwxjlmW6smfjnQ.text: Duck and waffle is great, it comes with duck confit, egg and waffle. Duck confit is so tasty and amazing. Highly recommend! Must reservation in advance, and the window seat is awesome.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

bfh7DLV8-pGnqmGiKLUUqw.text: THE BEST meal I've ever had in my life!!On 7/13, I was planning my trip to London which was exactly a month away (8/13). Every food blog about London was recommending this restaurant called Duck & Waffle, so I thought I had to check it out. I went on its site and found out I had to make a reservation (they take reservation up to two months in advance). To my surprise, Duck & Waffle was almost completely booked for a day that was an entire month away!! The only times available were at 7am and 7:30am. I am not a morning person, but I decided to make the commitment and made the reservation for 7:30am of my first full day. The night before the day of my reservation, I was in complete doubt I would wake up early enough to find myself at this restaurant. Miraculously, I woke up and made my way to the restaurant. Duck & Waffle is located on the 40th floor of the Heron Tower. To get up to the restaurant, I had to confirm my booking on the first floor and went through a security check. I also had to toss my water bottle. When I went up the elevator, I was amazed at the astonishing view of London. I was in awe. Perhaps it was early in the morning, I thought that the restaurant was significantly less crowded than I had imagined for a place that was fully booked an entire month in advance. I sat next to the window and enjoyed the view. Here is a description of what I ordered:1. Duck and waffle (£16): I never imagined this combination would make the perfect duo. The duck was perfectly roasted and it literally melted in my mouth. I can not describe in words the palatable sensations I experienced. In New York, an entree like this would cost at least $30, but I was able to experience this quality with a mere £16. I was so impressed. 2. Duck egg en cocotte (£13): While it was not as good as the duck and waffle, this mix of eggs, mushrooms, and truffles also well pleased my mouth. I would highly recommend it as a secondary entree. I was so tempted to order a dessert, but I had plans for high tea a few hours later so I resisted my temptations. I've never experienced anything like Duck & Waffle before and I would book flight tickets to London just so I can relive this incredible discovery. On another evening, I was passing by the restaurant and saw an incredibly long line of people in the chilly evening breeze waiting for a chance to enter this haven. I was tempted to get myself in line, but I had opt out again. -- taste / 5aesthetics / 5vibe / 5service / 5price for quality / 5OVERALL / 5

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. RIGHT: Duck and waffle LEFT: duck egg en cocotte

YJ_gP6boVmRrUm6H5MU3QQ.text: My family and I did a day trip to London and I was able to make a reservation the night before, we were pretty lucky. I called ahead of time to see if they could take us earlier since our group was hungry and the sever I spoke to let me know I could check in earlier and if they are able to take us they will. We made our way over and we were greeted by Catherine at the check in podium. I mentioned to her that I called regarding my reservation and she was unable to find my name. She rudely asked me to show her my confirmation email. She was still unable to find my reservation and asked what time I made the reservation and my sister chimed in and said "please look at her email, we have a confirmed reservation" then she finally let us up but replied "you may or may not have a reservation but I can let you up" The check in process with Catherine was horrible, she rolled her eyes and acted as if I didn't make a reservation. That's not what I expected from this place, as I came here 6 months ago for drinks. We let the hostess know the experience we had and they apologized which was appreciated. They sat us near the window and the service was great. Adrian and Manuel were amazing. The duck and waffle was better than I expected, I wasn't a fan of the syrup or waffle but the duck was moist and crispy. We also ordered the whole chicken, which was super moist and tasted amazing!

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

UAf88tHIcEZsNDN1t64BhA.text: Absolutely horrendous.  Getting into the place was ok - I've seen some folks complain about that but the guys we encountered were polite and professional - but everything else about this place was utterly atrocious.  We arrive a bit early and were asked to wait in the bar, a bar which only serves watery, I'll governed cocktails that taste completely revolting.  Then as our seating time rolls around the waitress looks like she's just been shot in the leg when I ask if our table is ready, especially after getting a dressing down for giving me, the paying customer, a condescending look - if you're going to do a pretentious job in a pretentious place then please try to get it right from the get go.And so to the food - I have honestly never been so repulsed by "restaurant" food in my entire life, and I've eaten at places big and small, expensive and street side, and this tops the list in terms of bland, paltry, lazy and tasteless fare, and that's being generous.  All dishes were small, flavourless, and wouldn't fit the bill in a weatherspoons.  I had theCrispy bbq pigs ears, which tasted like they'd been swept off the floor - utterly flavourless and putrid.  For mains I thought I'd try the duck and waffle, basically a poncy take on chicken and waffles, the American classic.  Now tell me, is a main course meant to leave you with a dry, barren mouth, gasping for water?  Because that's what this dish will do for you, it wasn't under prepared or cooked in any way, it was just so flavourless and bland it was a complete let down, and I ate maybe 30% of the very meagre portion placed in front of me. And of course when it was time to collect are clearly untouched plates they sent over a different waiter from the one who had served us to that point, a rather snake like approach they I only see deployed by high end ponce shacks that see a lot of underwhelmed customers, and who want to sweep away any negative feedback quickly.  And may I say that this must have been a particularly sour night for the cheffing and waiting staffs, as two other table within earshot were complaining loudly about the lack of quality and service.  Of course our second waiter just smiled and scurried away even though we were voicing our genuine concerns about the swill on show.  A real disappointment from a place I had been looking forward to dining at, it really was revolting food.

cEg_tafs7y-KaAyV90riiQ.text: Duck & Waffle is located on the 40th floor of 110 Bishopsgate in London.This building was completed in March 2011 and is now one of London's tallest buildings stretching 230m into the skyline. Guests are greeted at the restaurants private entrance to the building at ground level. Once in the building, one is escorted up the building to D&W via one of their 2 elevators. The elevator travels quickly taking only 40 seconds to reach the top at 5 mph. But slow enough to enjoy the breathtaking view. Duck & Waffle was designed by award winning architects CetraRuddy who intelligently has created vibrant atmosphere a place that welcomes guests 24/7 to sample D&W playful take on traditional British cuisine. CentraRuddy blended the breathtaking views of London, while providing a modern yet intimate and charming dining accommodation. The perfect blend of modern touches with old world materials is sheer brilliance. Duck and Waffle emphasizes local, rustic, seasonal and sustainable ingredients. Menu varies from breakfast, brunch, late night, all day, cocktails,wine, and desserts. They do offer special menu options on holidays.  Our selection during our visit:*BBQ-SPICED CRISPY PIG EARSSPICY OX CHEEK DOUGHNUTCELERIAC CARBONARA *DUCK & WAFFLE38 DAY AGED 500G ANGUS BONE-IN RIB-EYE*The items marked were my favorites. Duck and Waffle in my humble opinion is a must visit when in London.

BFk7hLreylTUcnl7N9E_5A.text: Fantastic and lovely are the two words I would use to describe this place. I came here in the evening and with the restaurant being on the 40th floor you'll get a great view of London on your way up. The bar you walk into is amazing in itself. The bartender is in the middle of the floor so seats are along the glass looking out over the city.I came with two friends and we wanted to try as much as possible. We ended up ordering eight dishes and they were all amazing but the highlights were the cornbread and dates wrapped in bacon. They bacon wrapped dates were tender and juicy. The sweetness of the dates and saltiness from the bacon was the perfect balance. The cornbread had a moist texture that came from the maple glaze and a little hint of spice from the jalapeños that was perfect.Every dish here was amazing so you can't go wrong with any item. I would highly recommend this place and plan on making it here whenever I'm in London.

JXUOIjHbQ5dkFP920-pFvg.text: Literally the worst customer service for their overrated food and dirty kitchen. Good thing they spend all of their PR money on getting into 'Where to eat in London' articles because you'd be better off at any other local diner and without the condescending attitude from everyone in the place.  It's a shame the liquor board doesn't know or doesn't care that they serve after hours with that shit attitude. No wonder sushi samba is a joke as well.Place is literally a joke. I've gone a few times as it's a decent drunk after hours spot to have an illegal glass of champagne along with over cooked eggs that were fired an hour ago with hard yolks. But if you have any self respect and don't need to be treated like an undeserving customer by a power tripping door man protecting the elevator for a restaurant with 4 tables sat; save your time. When their lease is out, they'll be gone as they've made the fatal mistake of treating customers like they're lucky to eat there (when they're not even busy) which you'll see is a consistent note in every review.  Be sure and bring an extra 50 pounds for the sad door guy if you want to eat some waffles. Also - their Head Chef, that even made the place palatable, left in April of this year (2018) so I can't imagine how much further downhill it's gotten.

oE96k3KQ_6JVSqs36saHVA.text: The only reservation time I could secure was 8 am on a Saturday - as much as I hated the alarm at 6 am, this was worth it.  The view was really gorgeous, the coffee was delicious, and my breakfast was excellent.  I shared the duck and waffle and the duck egg en cocette - both were delicious but the second was my favorite.  Another friend had the ox cheek benedict and I tried a bite, personally I found it average but he liked it. You're definitely paying for the experience as well as the food, but I thought overall it had value.

kMEAh91lAXkgFNuRt4x87g.text: Food: 3.5/5.0Service: 4.0/5.0Value: 3.5/5.0Decor: 4.5/5.0Overall: 4.0/5.0The restaurant was okay, but the point is to enjoy the amazing views of the city.  I came by an extremely early breakfast near opening time on a lark, and was probably one of the first five covers of the day - by the time I left, the place was basically packed.  Service was good, the duck and waffle was so-so (duck was dry, waffle okay), but the chance to sit by the windows was cool.  The restaurant is near the top of the building, and is accessed through a separate set of elevators that you get to from a street-side check-in.

NYFePT_9TLlJX4mhL4Fyxg.text: Dump. Inconsistent from phone service and downstairs bouncer. Waste of time. Touristy. Overplayed. Mediocre food.Avoid avoid avoid.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Cleo is rude.

-8kQNZaYCDeIw6xDMoJwcQ.text: We hopped into Duck & Waffle for a Sunday brunch and the restaurant was packed. It was bustling with hipsters which everyone was enjoying a great meal with a view on the 40th floor of the Heron Tower. We did not have too high of an expectation on the quality of food but it turned out to be surprisingly delicious. The Spring Vegetable Salad with Smoked Mozzarella was super fresh; their signature dish Duck & Waffle was amazingly tasty, the waffle was the best one I ever had; the Smoked Scottish Salmon on Flat Bread was memorable; and their Angus Bone-In Rib-Eye was juicy and cooked to perfection.   The best part was taking the floor to ceiling glass elevator down to the ground floor after the meal. It took less than 10 seconds to go from the 40th floor to the ground and you could see the view in 360 degree. We were able to feel the G-Force and it was almost liked a free fall. What an experience!

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

WMPFFg8ZqvLOQXYYDMe49w.text: I was in the rain and wanted to stop here for a drink. I was told that I couldn't get in because I was wearing jeans. There were plenty of people wearing jeans being let in. I guess I'll spend my money elsewhere ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

al8gl6y8oS7YG8gtoeSV7g.text: The duck wings were great! If you come here, you must get duck (unless you're a sad little vegetarian...). The pomegranate molasses is absolutely worth bone-sucking! Comes with slices of chili peppers if you like spice. Beet salad looked vibrant (did not try, just saw). Octopus was good, but wasn't the best. The duck was amazing, though, and would for sure come back for more!

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Cutest logo!!!

ObivXaYLsRtFNbr3LK3dlw.text: One of the best meals we had in London. It was hard to choose what we wanted to order because everything sounded so good. Landed on the broccoli, the celeriac carbonara, sea trout, and the duck and waffle. All the food was excellent.The only misstep was my cocktail. I ordered their version of an aviation and it was really excessively sweet. I couldn't drink it. The atmosphere is good, the service is great, the view is obviously great. Overall a really fun experience.

4TXt_voKisuslD0E8U9orA.text: Came here based on a number of locals recommending it. Was staying in Shoreditch so it wasn't too far of a walk. It's a bit fancier and harder to get a table without a reservation. They have a dress code and they have security screen you before going up. Did I mention it's located on the 40th floor of 110 Bishopsgate building - one of the taller buildings in London? It's adds to the ambiance and atmosphere. Enjoy the ride up!The menu had some cool options. We of course had to try the duck and waffle - that was my favorite. Crispy and fatty like peking duck and went well with the soft waffle and egg. The spicy ox cheek doughnut was a weird mix of flavors and the dough was pretty hard - too much for me. Enjoyed the rosemary and garlic bread more as a simple starter. Must check this place out at least once!One floor down is another restaurant and bar - go check it out if this one isn't your thing.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Elevator up!
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Duck and waffle (split portion)

EWCA5eMcH-i51BrEwHhRGw.text: After having been recommended this place, we showed up in the middle of the night without a reservation. The bar/waiting area was not my favorite vibe, but it was about 30 minutes to seat a party of 6 at 2 a.m. the restaurant area was chill with a beautiful view, the service was charming and exceptional, and the food was something to write home about. We had the spicy waffle, the eponymous duck&waffle, the duck donut, seared squash, and several deserts and cocktails. The vegetarian food was delicious as was the "surprise me" mocktail I requested. The rest of my party seemed beyond thrilled with the meat dishes and real cocktails. I'd recommend it as worth a reservation or worth a wait in the douchey bar area if you come looking for a great meal in the middle of the night.

ejbZMSuCYdu85JnjCZiwpA.text: Duck & Waffle served me, easily, one of the best meals I had in London. It wasn't just a meal - it was an experience. From start to finish, I was continually wowed by the dishes, the staff, the atmosphere, the view, and the cocktails. Everything we ordered was impressively delicious. The most noteworthy dish was (unsurprisingly) the Duck & Waffle - hence name. The duck was so succulent and crispy, the waffle was just right, and the dish was topped with an egg. After we finished that dish, we couldn't resist and ordered another entree of the Duck & Waffle.I dream about that meal from time to time. Needless to say, I have already booked my revisit in my upcoming trip to London and cannot wait to experience it again.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

CudUNstFYANAc6_u1KlVEQ.text: One of my favorite steaks in London... Discovered in the most unexpected location: Duck & Waffle.The 24-hour restaurant that sits atop the Heron tower just above Sushi Samba.  It's the "highest restaurant in London", sitting on the 40th floor and sharing it's cocktail bar with Sushi Samba below.  The views are amazing and the clientele and venue are not over-the-top posh, which I like.Their main dish is of course the Duck & Waffle.  It's composed of a crispy duck confit leg atop a Belgian waffle.  It's then topped with a fried duck egg and served with mustard maple syrup.  Indulgent, rich, buttery and perfect any time of day as long as your arteries are in working order!Back to the matter at hand though, the 500g Angus, bone-in ribeye is my new favorite steak in London.  And I never saw it coming.The Longhorn beef is sourced from Thirsk, in north Yorkshire.  It's served with a whipped marmite hollandaise sauce, assorted greens and pearl onions, sliced on a sharing platter - and I swear it's got bone marrow in there somewhere!  My only complaint is that I have to share.  The beef is juicy and succulent, full of flavor and cooked just right.  It's quite stunning that a non-beef-centric restaurant has stormed into my favorite steak considering the company Duck & Waffle keeps in the City mile.Other signature dishes include a 'spicy ox cheek donut served with apricot jam and smoked paprika sugar' or the 'foie gras creme brulée with buttered roasted lobster and toasted brioche.'  Also, some cocktails I'd recommend:The Hemmingway - Bacardi Superior rum, maraschino liqueur, lime and grapefruit juices - clarified.The Roasted Cosmo - Grey Goose Le Citron, orange liqueur, roasted bone marrow infusion, cranberry conserve, lime.I go into more detail on my website: beeffanatic.com/2015/02/…

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. The infamous duck & waffle
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Ribeye sliced steak at Duck and Waffle

MyFjbn6ODhX2DlCpnumefQ.text: I wasn't too impressed. The place is located at one of the highest if not the highest points in the city, and does offer a good panoramic view, but just remember London doesn't really have a skyline to speak of. We came on a Monday for lunch and had to wait quite a bit for a table even though the place was less than half full. We finally were allowed a table but only "for an hour." And when we asked if we could sit by the window we were told those tables were all reserved. I got the smoked eel and a coffee and my friend the eponymous "duck and waffle." The eel was way to salty for me to savor the actual meat, and the coffee was uncharacteristically strong and bitter. I think my palate was pretty much shut down after finishing the eel since all I wanted was water to douse away the briny taste on my tongue. The prices aren't as high as you'd expect from a high-end London restaurant, so that partially made up for the experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. smoked eel

Qp4Ct0yTWTm4_6RHft0MyQ.text: Doorman literally showed us a middle finger, denied not only entry but an explanation. Quite shocking. Duck you, Duck and Waffle

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Uexplainably denied us entry, and physically showed us a middle finger. Check cctv footage. Never again

_GxNeQ7bP-0RqThfZJrIuQ.text: Tips: 1. Be sure to make reservation, or the security/reception won't let you in for free.2. Get the duck & waffle, you won't regret it. 3. It opens 24 hour, reservation after 10 pm is easy to get. ===MY CONFESSIONS FOR DUCK&WAFFLE BELOW YOU MAY STOP READING===Oh Duck & Waffle, how I missed you. I was living in London for a limited time and while I was there, I wanted to try as many different restaurants as possible. Therefore I rarely go to the same restaurant twice, even if they are good and close to me. I also don't like going to places that's not a direct tube ride away. I've gone out of my way (took a bus and everything) to go to Duck & Waffle 3 times in 3 months. It was well worth it! If I want to take any visitor to a restaurant in London, Duck & Waffle would arguably be my top choice. Why? The view! The hours! The ambiance! The service! The price! And let's not forget about the food! This REALLY is the whole package. View: On the 40th floor of Heron Tower (one of the tallest building in London), the view is incredible. If you want to impress your date, make sure to get one of the tables by the window(there are many of those). With the tower bridge, the tower of London, and the city under your feet, it's hard to find a better view.Hours:24 x 7. In London. That's what I'm talking about.Always make a reservation before you go. It's very busy during normal meal hours, but if you are night owl like me, a table is always available at midnight. There should be more places like this...everywhere! Ambiance: It's one of those places that manages to provide an exquisite dining experience without making you feel intimidated. Low soft light, spacious, trendy decor, lively crowd, perfect.  Service:Absolutely delightful. All 3 times the service has been attentive, efficient, and super friendly. Price: Is a place like this going to cost an arm and a leg you asked? I've had some shockingly expensive meals in London, and this place certainly doesn't look cheap. But you will be surprised. For a dinner with appetizers, a main course and a drink it costs about  £45 per person. To put it in context, it is cheaper than an afternoon tea in the Dorchester Hotel.Food:Finally it comes to the food. Here are the things I've tried:- carlingford rock oysters: You can never go wrong with some fresh oysters. They make me happy.- bbq-spiced crispy pig ears: So wonderful that I couldn't stop eating them. My friend had to hide it from me or I'd be stuffed before the main courses.  It came in a brown paper bag with a duck & waffle seal, which was a lovely touch.- spicy ox cheek doughnut: I was quite full when I tried this so I'm not sure if I could do it justice. It was interesting and original, but I don't think it's my thing. The apricot jam was tasty though.- foie gras crème brûlée: I felt obligated to order foie gras since it's no longer legal in California. It was delicious, creamy, smooth, perfect with some dark rye bread. It's a bit heavy for an appetizer for two people, may be better to share with 3 or 4.- duck & waffle: If you go to a restaurant that's named after one of its dishes, you order that dish. You'd be glad to follow this rule here at duck & waffle. The duck leg is so crispy on the outside and so juicy inside. The portion is perfect for sharing between 2.- smoked scottish salmon: The portion is big! It may not stand out as much as the other dishes but it's still very tasty. The cocktail options are excellent as well. Duck & Waffle is stylish but not pretentious, creative and delicious, reasonable priced for such high quality, and there are always window seats available after midnight ;) I'd go back there in a heartbeat if it's not 11-hour flight away.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Lovely view
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Oyster ... So good

7NggLCudCTBtLgu742W_xw.text: I can die happy now. Either that or at least am worthy to go on Food Network's "Best I Ever Ate" breakfast edition. I came here on a Friday morning around 830 with no reservations. I heard it was popular but I assumed 1 person this early shouldn't be too hard to accommodate. Well I was wrong. Luckily the staff could see tis lonely American solo traveler was desperate to get her hands on some good eats and they said they could double check for me. After a few minutes, a hostess appeared, took my jacket to the coat check and said they'd be happy to accommodate me if I promised to stay no longer than 40 minutes as to not ruin their reservation schedule. I said, "deal!"Service was lovely. Never felt like they were annoyed at me in any sense, even though I crashed the party basically. I started with a personal pot of coffee for 4 pounds. Delicious coffee with a container of steamed/frothy milk (I was impressed). Of course I had to get the duck and waffle (I mean that's what the place is named after!) It was 15 pounds. Crisp half waffle with a fried duck leg and topped with a perfect sunny side up egg that is lightly sprinkled with coarse sea salt. On the side is the maple syrup mixed with mustard seeds. Usually I am a freak about keeping my eggs away from my syrup (i know I'm weird) but this meal is meant to be eaten with a little bit of each part in every bite. Oh and the views! From the 40th floor in the Heron Tower you have perfect views of London's overcast skyline. Also, did I mention that I am 99% positive that JK Rowling was at a table next to me?!? I tried to snap a secret photo but she caught me staring...whoops.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. View from the 40th floor in the heron tower.
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. THE duck and waffle with mustard syrup....the BEST thing I ate in London.
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Personal pot of coffee with milk, cubes, and amazing views :)

q6cHqDSZSQxfVAYRTy-d6Q.text: Probably the coolest rooftop restaurant/bar I've ever been to. Seriously AMAZING views, so chic and trendy, so expensive! But it's London, right?Duck and Waffle was right across from our hotel in London and I'd been reading all about it in Time Out, foodie blogs and twitter, so it was a must-do on my list while visiting my favourite city. The restaurant is open 24/7 and the menu is highly flexible, so you can choose if you'd like just a taste or a full meal. It's hard to get a table in the main dining room without a reservation. It's not too hard to walk in to get a small bar table with service on a weeknight, however. Cocktails were strong and delicious. What took the cake was the SPICY OX CHEEK DOUGHNUTS. Without a doubt, one of the best creative bar food concoctions I've ever tried. I didn't try the signature dish (ie duck and waffles) but I saw it being passed off to the table next door and felt my heart drop. Will have to order next time! Several months later, we're still talking about Duck and Waffle. It's a little trendier than the Shard and slightly less stuffy too. Check it out.

-54gJQHaNW5A196exKgpjQ.text: I often stick a lot of background detail into my reviews just for fun, but in this case it might be more useful than usual. Because if you're thinking about this place on the spur of the moment, then I'll warn you to think again. Unless it's the wee small hours of the morning, then hallelujah it's the answer to your prayers for something in London to be open at this time! Otherwise you need to book in advance, and if it falls into 'normal mealtimes' then you needed to make a reservation a month ago.I was planning a girly brunch before heading off to work in Edinburgh for a few weeks, and with 3 weeks' notice the only time left on a Saturday morning for 6 people was 8.30am. Not ideal, but we took it. The hype about this place was enough for my girls to gallantly get out of bed earlier than they would for work - I was definitely feeling the love :)The other thing to mention is that a booking is not a booking unless you reconfirm with them or their answering machine at least a day before - they'll call you a couple of days in advance to check this. You've been warned.The morning itself started grey and miserable, and we were grateful to get inside anywhere let alone the awesome lift ride to the 40th floor here. As with Sushisamba that whoosh of an entrance is guaranteed to impress (or at least leave you a bit wobbly at the top). A few twisting turning tiled corridors later, past the bar and views down onto the gherkin, and we were seated by the floor-to-ceiling windows on the north side.Thankfully (and before the girls could complain) the clouds soon cleared up and we got some gorgeous views outside - I'm a sucker for being at height (not just my 6ft frame I mean). It's the views that really sell the place looks-wise as I wasn't sure what the décor was saying - the tiles in the corridor suggest something Mediterranean but the dining room itself is quite plain and unfussy, with wooden tables along the windows and booths in the centre.My mate had made the mistake of looking at the brunch menu online, but at 8.30am that was a bit of a stretch and we were handed slightly more restricted breakfast menus instead. It was a bit disappointing for my 4 veggie mates to find they couldn't get a veg version of the full english on the menu - I hadn't checked veg choices in advance as I'd just assumed they'd be covered at brunch. A couple got the Colombian Eggs with me - avocado and organic eggs on sourdough toast. I got the eggs scrambled and added chorizo on top; it was yum but boy I could still taste that chorizo hours later!Others resorted to building their own breakfast from the sides - toast, hash browns, mushrooms etc, which all came out beautifully presented. After round one I had a tasty latte and we got waffles to share - by then it was late enough to pick from the brunch menu. We had one with honey-glazed banana and nutella, and one with poached rhubarb and honeycomb (both with ice cream obv). I knew I'd like the first one, but unexpectedly think I preferred the second - not sure what they did to it but rhubarb didn't taste this good the last time I tried it!The service is stressed but smiley at the door, whilst the waiters were attentive in refilling tap water but not what I'd call warm. The ordering process was more of a struggle than it needed to be as he didn't seem to understand 'vegetarian' and tried to get everyone to add salmon or chorizo to their dishes. Still I did like the little touch of noting who ordered what, so they could bring the food straight out to each person without asking whose dish it was.I think I was expecting a little more from the food as it's pricey for what you get, but I guess that's not a surprise in this setting. I wouldn't rush back for brunch but I'd like to try it at a different part of the day. Get your diary out and plan a visit if you haven't then, but use it wisely - whether it's on your special someone, or your mom (or maybe your mom is your special someone), or a guest from abroad. Just be ready to catch them when they totter out that lift!
