yKZjnpoCsuZzy3TvnR1xOA.text: The bald Russian mother trucker guarding the door is the only reason for this heartbreak of a review. The night of the London attacks, a group of friends and I were wandering like lost souls on the streets of East London. Starving, we decided to have Duck & Waffle. Uber was shut down, the tube was down, and cabs were extinct. When we approached the door. This bald man, "Alex," said they couldn't accommodate us because "one of us had had too much to drink." We were all sober and tried to explain ourselves to this guard. He then proclaimed we were "too American." This is a disgrace of an establishment. Sack his arse

ZwSzLgoaqg14wtymayz4uQ.text: If you want a great view over London with good food this is a the place to be. Don't forget to reserve in advanced this place is usually booked out but open for 24 hours. We had some duck & waffle there and really enjoyed the view over London and the food was also very good.If you want to take pictures professional cameras aren't allowed. You have to take your iPhone instead and the stuff is very aware of this.

A6einVzb5k-vKjaWML6_fA.text: One star this time. Why? Because the bouncer had his head up his behind and wouldn't let me in to get a coffee because of my trainers (which are squeaky clean and have had numerous compliments, but which I also have to wear at the moment because of an injury on my Achilles' tendon). When I pointed out someone else he has let in wearing trainers he responded that it was ok because they had a reservation. Then he started telling me it takes a month to get a reservation and this has been the policy since they opened and I should check the website and all the other stuff you don't want to hear when someone on a silly power trip has denied you access to your favourite place in London and ignored your foot injury (not that the injury should matter).This was one of my favourite places in London but I'm not going there again unless I get an apology.It's 2015 guys. Nobody else cares what shoes I'm wearing, so what difference does it make to you?

YFngqh6ewAsxsHvSk0Qe4Q.text: 5 starts for ambiance and location! The most beautiful views of London.   Not stuffy for how nice it is. 5 stars for the bread.  We had the garlic and rosemary bread and it was AMAZING. 5 stars for the main courses.  We had the classic duck and waffle and the pea and ricotts ravioli.   Both dishes were cooked to perfection. Must get a booking early.....we had over a month wait for a lunch reservation.   Totally worth the wait!

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Garlic & Rosemary bread
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Duck & Waffle and the Pea, Ricotta ravioli

yC_DEjsDSuv6qnO5xfqeYg.text: Amazing food with a breath taking view of London. Every dish was great and wine recommendation was perfect. Staff is also extremely nice.

yk1Svd_2_dBjDgU-aAVhqA.text: A little pretentious for my liking.  Sure, Duck & Waffle provides a great view of London 24/7, but their service and food offerings are really subpar.  We came on a late Thursday night at about midnight, and were lucky to get booth seating.  The bar is definitely busy with what I presume to be tourists/visitors.  When the bartender/server came to take our order, his sarcastic remarks came off as rude and condescending.  Not exactly a great first impression, but whatever.  Disregarded and continued on with our happy days.  Later on in the night, he came back to check on us, and told us to move out feet off the seats and that we could not use them as foot rests.  Okay dude... no one was going to sit there anyways...  Abided, but displeased.  As the night we went on, we wanted to grab a couple of small bites with our drinks  AND let me tell you, don't bother.  There were maybe about 6 items on the menu, and only the bacon wrapped dates and crispy pig ears sounded somewhat promising.  We didn't order them cause they sounded lackluster anyways and tried to ask if we could order at the restaurant.  It's 1:30 AM with plenty of seating.  When asking the hostess, she said that because we had no reservations, we would not be allowed to seat.  Normally, I'd understand if it was super busy or a busy time, but it's 1 freaken 30 AM with 10+ tables available.  What the heck dude?!  Even if this was truly a restaurant policy that the hostess is simply trying to abide by, I am extremely disappointed with Duck & Waffle's service and how they treat and talk to their patrons.  So many people hyped this place up as a great place to dine and hang out with, but it was nothing but a huge let down.  I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone.

KRmJMmfxu1THLqez1YJx_w.text: Lovely view and lovely food. It has a stunning view of all London. I would highly recommend this place for a late brunch or even after a night out :)

ljWD-c0N6Sgf7w-t2sn5fA.text: This is by far the best place I have visited in terms of atmosphere and overall experience. Food is good but not the reason why I would go back. Unique!

iJXH66pGN-CeGlZdqzTtrQ.text: My 2nd time to Duck and Waffle (last time was a good 3-4 years ago pre-kids...) and it really didn't disappoint. Ok so some things are a little tiresome like the security guards outside acting like you're trying to get into Studio 54 in its prime but once the queuing and telling off for not following the dress code (our bad on the trainers...) was out of the way... and a quick trip through the metal scanners (had to leave my knuckle dusters and uzi at the door... :-( ) it was all gravy!Here's some great points*The super fast lift in itself is great fun, I'd happily ride it all day long like a roller coaster.*Cool casual bar - lots of opportunity to hang out away from diners.*Super friendly staff who were really on it all night as service was excellent *Great wine list - with the full range of affordable and not so affordable on offer. *The views are wunderbar - really amazing, the best in London. *The food - oh so great - highlights were the octopus, the oxcheek doughnuts (so so good) and the desserts to die for. We had the tasting menu and it seemed to be never ending - in a good way!Special occasions, for fans of heights or just because you want to embrace and enjoy life - Duck and Waffle is the perfect place for 101 reasons.

3CbzdWArcWrtGnnCv_VcGg.text: I mean. They do a GIANT doughnut, rolled in sugar, with the softest, tenderest ox cheek shredded inside.  And you can look out, 360, as far as the eye can see, from one of the highest view points in London.  What exactly else do you need to know?!!!TBH it's an experience and a half. The food is excellent, the service is impeccable (though with that London snobbish feel you come to expect around the area - shout out to the two jaunty club-style bouncers at the entrance downstairs)  It's not cheap but it's not prohibitively expensive either. Another weird highlight - the lift. It reminded me of Roald Dahl's Charlie & The Glass Elevator. It's on the outside of the building and gives you an ear-popping, wholly dizzying ride right to the top. Don't look down. (Or do, you dare devil you!!)As previous reviewers have said, make sure you book well in advance (as in, at least a month or two), or you're unlikely to get a normal eating hour. (Unless you like to eat dinner at 4am - if you do, look at you, living life to the max, not having to do with waiting lists!!!)Can't wait to go back.

ygopem9_z3ymiguAFgNOIg.text: The view is one of the best you'll find in the city. The staff however are rude. As we walked in, we were handed the least practical cocktail menu ever devised. It took a while to look through it and choose what we wanted. Our server rushed us to order, and not to mention stank of BO. It is extremely pretentious and expensive (£17 per drink). I'd be happy to pay that for the view, but the service is not up to it. I asked for the optional 12.5% service charge to be removed from the bill and my server, who must have known he was being rude in the first place, wanted to interrogate me about what was bad with the service. If I were you, I'd just ride up the lift, see the view, then head back down.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Same menu, but without someone holding open all the doors.
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Who would think that a menu like this would be a good idea?

x_prIAgdwDKhnCO8vLrlsw.text: I loved the food!The fact that you can do anything from brunch to dinner is also a massive plus.Liked the website too.

r_5UjMGOwyAEzmPxw4K0sw.text: Amazing food, great service. Had a lay over in London from midnight to noon. By the time I got into the city this happen to be the only place open. Although underdressed we headed up to the 40th floor and got seated next to the window and had a beautiful view of the city light. The duck and waffle was incredibly delicious, the flavors were like nothing I've ever tasted. Also enjoyed the short rib sloppy joe, another dynamic and original creation! Highly recommend this place!

FwT1N5mIDESJPeGJADtk3A.text: Great atmosphere and decent prices! The octopus appetizer was amazing. I also had the Duck & Waffle although I'm not a huge waffle fan. It was decent, although I normally don't like a mixture of savory and sweet taste together. The cocktails were mediocre too but it's a great place to have a not super expensive dinner for a A-list setting.

DpoWOza3Ua9hJBNZ1HUmtw.text: Excellent as always. Price is high, and reservations can be hard to get. Be sure to get a window table!

p4j6C6rYtRoynVN7_870dQ.text: Was brought here by a local during my stay in London. AMAZING VIEW. I came here for dinner so the night view was great. Decent number of food selection but all are very interesting. Neat decor but a little loud since it is a fairly small room packed with people. Tried the duck & waffle which is a weird combination but it works. Would recommend anyone visiting London and also to impress people who are visiting London ;)

DTZhYanllxdQLqw7VogAuQ.text: £35 for 2 terrible drinks, worst music ever, huge queue for the lift, and it smells of wee. Overkill officious staff and we were warned gravely that if we went all the way up, there was no guarantee that we would ever get a seat. Save your money - don't go to Duck and Waffle. Blech.

aWWf-t3gmCAGj52WR_bJiQ.text: The view is incredible!!! I'm not a duck fan, so ended up ordering something else on the menu. Great spot to have cocktails and mingle with friends!

wNfnjbUdnqsKKJuYioiF5A.text: Very nice view up on the 40th floor. Service impeccable but most importantly food was good. Good for big groups who want to share food tapas style. Fish was cooked very well. Get the n'duja & gruyère baked bread, and whole roast sea bass 'forestier'.

AB6myG9hhzKsiuWyYcAvgg.text: The last time I came to Duck and Waffle, I loved it. What's not to love?  Duck. Waffle. Fried Egg. Syrup. One of the best views in London. Maybe the desserts, but who needs dessert when you have duck and waffles. I came back with friends at 2:30 in the morning for reasons I won't go into here. I just want to go up and down in that lift swooshing through London with empty streets and glittering lights. I totally would if the doorman didn't look so capable at cracking jaws. The restaurant was virtually deserted besides a large man with a classy e-cigar, guffawing and talking constantly while a coterie of his "model friends" ate very little and laughed airily.We got the corner table with the best views in the house. It was a "I'm flying Jack" moment. *Cries a little*. We shared a duck and waffle, and a paper packet of crispy BBQ pigs ears, which came out within 5 minutes. The combination of flavours and textures is just so perfect. The mix between sweet and savoury is ace. If we were hungrier and it wasn't the middle of the night I'd have gotten the ox-cheek doughnut because that is sensational. I wish there was an option to pay a bit extra for a waiter to cut and assemble each mouthful, because even though it is so delicious the allocation of flavours can become quite hard work. This would definitely tip the decadence barometer over the edge though. This must be the only place where I want exactly the same things. I'm sure the other dishes are great and everything but who cares at all when there is duck and waffle. London at night is something else, seeing buildings you know so well from above, sparkling like little toys. Plus the hand cream in the bathrooms smells lovely. There's no snobby veneer of exclusivity, just amazing food in an amazing setting.

JPW-yDmNNSvgVEKup0zSow.text: Lived in London for four months searching for the best and this truly is one of the best meals I had in London:1. The view The elevator is a quick ride to the top and once you enter Duck & Waffle you realize how beautiful the restaurant is. Natural light seeps through the large windows and you can see all of the city in your seat. It's truly a breathtaking view that enhances your overall dining experience.2. The duck & waffle I cannot emphasize enough how delicious this dish is. The duck and waffle is a creative and perfect combination! It's popularity is understood the minute you take a bite.

1FeFMFuoqVJJpMxzhjx-EA.text: Great food great view but impossible to get a booking these days anymore. Its really a must do if u want to impress guests in London. Try the bacon wrapped dates they are to die for. Great for any time of the day brunch lunch or dinner. Better value for money than sushi samba down one floor below. If u can't get a reservation definitely try to go and have a drink at the bar the view and interior is well worth it

idJj0MaODax80eYBIivTcg.text: Came here on a sunny Sunday for brunch. Being a restaurant with good views of London, there is a lot of glass, that with an open kitchen makes for a rather warm restaurant. Wasn't that impressed with the overall decor of the restaurant, one of the views is ruined by a large (and a bit tacky) hanging decoration thing.Nit picking aside I wish I could eat duck and waffles everyday! It was amazing. Weirdly though this dish is under the section for dishes to share, I'm not one for sharing my food and it's not served in away suitable for sharing. The brunch options sounded very good. A bit gutted the ox cheek doughnuts had run out by the time we ordered. Being a greedy guts I was the only one to have a pud (yes I know I came for brunch). I chose a rhubarb baked Alaska, incredibly pretty and delicious. Cocktails are on the expensive side, but then you're paying for the view.As much as loved the duck and waffle I won't rush back.

HzuJLausw7wmeuY3NUl47A.text: We arrived at about 1.30am confident we'd just walk in. Apparently not. We joined the queue where the door staff told all the people in front of us very firmly it was reservations and guest list only and sent them away into the night. We told him we'd like to come in and he very charmingly said yes of course sir. Ah the vagaries of London door policies. And we were four gnarly men with nary a pretty lass between us to sway him. Anyway up we went through the night stars in the glass elevator to the top of the tower, worth the visit alone. The staff up there were charming and knew their stuff. The room is fabulous at night, and the food was good. A memorable evening

hMPhywI2KXznsQKVGjM-qA.text: I managed to find a dinner reservation on a monday night at 10 (the hardest part)! Came here with my parents and we liked it.This is the highest restaurant in town and I must say the view is amazing and the atmosphere is also very relaxed. I can't imagine how stunning it is in the morning with the light coming from the huge windows.The place is impressive and the food is good. The menu has some particular things, we had three different entrees and they were all very good. The main we got is the combination that gives the name to the restaurant: crispy duck served with waffles! If you don't like sweet plates than don't take it. Very nice desserts and quite extensive (and expensive) wine list.A place to check out, it is open 24/7 and also has a bar!

2tHcK1ycDwYd8n3pIdZe8A.text: Awful food. We tried a number of the allegedly signature dishes, including the sea bass and the oxtail and the namesake duck and waffles. Everything was mediocre at best. If you are a tourist who is out of your element and values underwhelming food and service, this is the place for you. Otherwise Duck & Waffle is to be avoided like the plague.

mSe51F681HbjP1_2f35ZfQ.text: Awesome place to experience a more upscale version of English fare.  The restaurant itself has a cool interior and ambiance.  Service was great and food was very good but it was on the heavy side. We ordered some interesting dishes... tripe, pig cheeks and rabbit hearts anyone? Not for everyone but we loved it!I would definitely recommend this place and would probably go back here again if ever in London.

pwvQwZWjcrlIuYWYhw_M5w.text: While the views are amazing, the food does not live up to the hype. This was unfortunate because I love creative food and have an adventurous palette. This place feels more like a tourist trap than a serious eats place.

jjqYn5hKX5aTZbcSl90HQA.text: great setting. Nice food but very pricey. Definitely 1st date material

D2u8pZhPoN7Z4KVmppyTdw.text: My boyfriend and I had a fantastic experience here. The wine selection is very good, and the food was delicious. We had a very lovely view of London, and from where we were seated, we were able to watch the sunset. We had to make a reservation 2 months before to get a spot on a Sunday night. Overall good experience.

lHC5C_qwUit0_XU1z1gfig.text: Took my sister and her significant other who live in Dubai to Duck and Waffle in order to show off london coolest skyscraper and unusual combination of food. Having booked for weekend brunch three weeks in advance, I was determined to impress them We're they impressed? Yes with regard to the food But turned out every building in Dubai is 40 floors so nothing impressive about the location or the view !!! Back to the main experience- the restaurant is very trendy in decor, the food menu is certainly creative and the taste is divine It is definitely a place to go to for good times and food And the waitress was friendly too (bonus)

XCjG7mCBlHF8rDE2VqOCJQ.text: Had duck and waffle at the Duck & Waffle. This was my first time going to such a talked-about restaurant with my friends and I really loved the place! First off, the journey up to the restaurant was spectacular. The lift goes up at high-speed and you can notice the quick change in pressure with your ears. Perhaps I was already so used with slow lifts that I had to wait ages for, the experience was amazing. (haha I'm so easily contented)Anyway, I loved the Duck and Waffle dish that I ordered. I had a grande-sized Caramel Macchiato an hour ago from Starbucks so I couldn't really stomach anything else. Although it was probably my first time eating such a strange combination of food together but despite the strangeness, the food was delicious! I loved how crispy and succulent the duck confit was and although the waffle and duck egg were merely satisfactory, the duck confit more than made up for it. The mustard maple syrup wasn't too sweet and good enough for my tastes. Loved the service in this restaurant. Although we were bunch of cheapskates and ordered only tap water, we received no grudge and our glasses were consistently filled, table cleared and wiped off of any noticeable dirt (although it's something trivial, it's not a gesture practised by a lot of restaurants). So a big thank you to the waiter in charge of our table for such a great service - this is the first time whereby i gladly paid the 12.5% charged to the bill. The only downside of this entire dining experience was the view. It was foggy tonight so there wasn't much to see and the sky was still bright so no night lights either. Will definitely come back to this lovely place at a better time. Till then! :)

sbOMzBHeVLZxRrL0r8AqXw.text: Fantastic!  A beautiful view with delicious food and impeccable service.  We ate at a Michelin restaurant two nights prior that did not compare to our experience here.I've had pig ears at many places and it seems many cannot get it right.  They were delicious here!  Also, the foie gras creme brûlée was amazing.  Presentation was great as well on many things.On a side note, they play great music too.We will be back on our next visit to London.

awqK1xAK6PHhTe0FwsjSEw.text: If you'd like to eat during "normal" hours you're going to have to do some up-front planning and book a reservation months in advance however, there's clearly a good reason for that--this place is fantastic. If you can swing a table next to the windows overlooking the city your group/date will think you're a hero. The outside bar just two floors down is a perfect spot to start your night with a cold drink and an amazing view of London. If you've got a reservation at the restaurant you can bypass the queue for the elevator. Another reason for doing so. The plates are perfect for sharing so it's best to just go HAM and order a flurry of starters and main plates to enjoy with your table. The Duck and Waffle is a must. Pig ears are not my thing, generally, but give these a try and you'll probably be as surprised as I was. Oxcheek filled doughnut...YES! For those who have been to Sugarcane in Miami this place is just as good. The service was good. The food comes out as and when it's ready so you experience waves of deliciousness. The bar just outside the restaurant has an interesting open format concept. An after dinner drink might be worth it  Prices are a bit rough so be prepared. A good value when considering the views of London, the quality of the food, and the atmosphere. Sometimes you just have to spend the money anyway so go for it!

a75mdcBsFsmVHmtxpdfDpw.text: The food was pretty decent. I typically got the duck and waffle. The waffle was yum the deck was tender and flavoured.. they got my egg jusr how i like it so that was a bonus.Service was also great. VIEW WAS AMAZING. That and a few glasses of champagne I was all smiles. You have to book wayyyy in advance though only downside. Lucky we got in last minute due to advance cancellation.

0eabXar2aC_gGj4Fgv1d8Q.text: More than handy and some of the best views in the capital. I'd certainly keep this one for a special occasion. After being whisked up the glass elevator, you're thrown into a modern and clean restaurant with views all around you. A really nice stocked bar, where the gin and tonics really work!We had a small table for three and the staff made every effort to sit us down with the best view. It was amazing, although probably not one for anyone who doesn't like heights. We all went straight for the duck and waffle (you've got to really) and what a weird but beautiful plate of food. There's something new and exciting about the crisp and sweet waffle with a tender chunk of duck meat. The dish was served with a sweet maple mustard sauce and it probably lasted all of 4 minutes. It was too good not to keep digging in. We only went for the meal and left to keep exploring the bar, but both the starters and desserts looked incredible. Certainly one to keep in mind with Christmas approaching!!

9LlZCp0WJqOx_u2jGRzl4w.text: 24 hours a day of good food and drinks, If you are an early riser or a late late partier, this is an AMAZING place to watch the sun rise over London.

J9nr4fhWKmzl-mxVOdhJoQ.text: Wow! What a view! I had to book quite a while in advance for Duck & Waffle but so glad I did. Everything about the evening was great. From the super fast lift that shoots up one of London's tallest building in seconds to the decor and the food. We both had a drink at the lively bar first while waiting for our table and the service was friendly. Once in the restaurant we were amazed by the view from our table. It was a lovely clear night and all the famous sights of London we're lit up for us. We both ordered the duck & waffle of course as well as some other  plates to share. All the food was great and very filling which isn't always the case as the more popular places. I would highly recommend D&W for any time of day as I hear they have amazing breakfast too. Can't wait to go back.

_kpGiF8I9aR1O_IF34t1nQ.text: Great late night/early morning place. Dishes are reasonably priced but drinks are expensive. The breakfast (and especially the duck & waffle) are great. Make sure to book ahead of time otherwise count on having to wait for a table.

MOKwYU3bRLjMg9gX0Rk6zQ.text: The night started with us living it up on the 40th floor at Duck and Waffle, and I made the night even better by ordering a dark and stormy cocktail which came in a brown bag and brown bottle. Like a homeless person! So shabby chic. Although, I don't think any homeless person has stunning views of london like duck and waffle does. So, duck and waffle is KIND of like tapas, but not really tapas. We tried everything from goat cheese, to rabbit, to octopus, to an oxcheek donut, and not forgetting the signature duck and waffle. Sounds a bit like YGO's extreme eating adventures now. Actually, we didn't order the octopus, but i said oxcheek and that sounded like octopus. So that's a gauge on how noisy it can get. I LOVED the rabbit, it was quite possibly my favourite dish of the night and it easily trumped the signature dish, because I don't think duck and maple syrup work. I like duck, I like maple syrup, smush them together, ehhh, doesn't do anything for me. We also got a rice pudding dish, that tasted  bit like thouse free ones I get from the turkish restaurants in haringay. and the ones in haringay tastes a bit better. A great place to take guests to show them London and also we saw Matt Groening!

rA85A8o5MoL6ICuBeCnZ2Q.text: Great place to eat, staff were so friendly and nice. Food just lovely and such amazing views of London 40 floors up :)

WpylTssWJ3g765CRIWzZ_Q.text: Duck & Waffle is unique, extraordinary.. but also slightly overpriced.The uniqueness? Its 40th floor location and those views. They claim to be the highest restaurant in the country, at exactly 200m off the ground, and I can believe them. Quite simply it's like nothing else in London (or indeed the rest of the country). The smooth ascent (or descent) by lift is quite a thrill, and as a result, either the stylish bar or restaurant has to be a great place to impress someone, say on a date.Also extraordinary about it is its 24 hour nature. I'm a big fan of that, and hitherto coming here, the only 24 hour London restaurant I knew of was Vingt Quatre in Fulham. Needless to say, Duck & Waffle is far superior experience.The service is excellent too. Quick, responsive and very helpful with last-minute requests. My girlfriend's birthday was due a few days after I swung by with fellow Yelpers as part of the Classy Christmas Crawl (full credit here to the mighty Andrew M) and I wondered if it was possible to surprise her with a lit candle on a small dessert plate. No problem at all they replied and out came the plate just as we were preparing to pay the bill. Result: a hearty group rendition of 'happy birthday' and one delighted girlfriend.The food however, though good, is rather overpriced. I had to go for the signature Duck and Waffle dish, partly due to its eponymous nature but also because I'm a massive fan/glutton of waffles. It sounds great, and it was good, but consisting of Duck leg on waffle with grain mustard maple syrup for £17, really it's just a rather expensive, posher version of bacon on waffles or pancakes with maple syrup, and in a smaller quantity too. The dessert waffles are also pricey: at £8.50, they're the most expensive I've seen. That said, the other dishes opted for by the rest of the group did look interesting and as the waiter said, given that we were eating (literally) into the early hours, the menu was more restricted than usual.I do wonder a bit what market D&W is aiming for. Its 200 metre elevation gives it a huge advantage over competitors such as Galvin at Windows or the Oxo Tower, so in some ways I'm surprised that they haven't upped the ante by going for haute cuisine outright. Maybe it does during the day, but that's certainly not the impression I get.Still, Duck and Waffle is extraordinary, unique and 100% worth checking out, whichever hour of the 24 you find yourself in the area.

zUQaWX3_OJuWYWF6irsTdQ.text: If you enjoy a Saturday night at Shoreditch, and want to watch sunrise afterwards with a classy breakfast.. You are in the right place.

lCltHniPxU9UvrhNrgQywQ.text: This place was so amazing to stop and have a drink/bite to eat. We made reservations but they were for am instead of pm so I was a bit agitated over that and the snobby hostess which cut us no break. Drinks were amazing and the appetizers were great. I probably won't ever be back but I'm glad I stopped by for the view and great drinks.

63-vnq4mHmcl8R3JqGcHBA.text: Don't get me wrong, Duck and Waffle has some pretty good grub, and insanely spectacular views. For all the hype, though, I'm not entirely convinced it's worth the (pretty steep) price you pay. Also, it's not great for vegetarians, unless you really like roasted beets and different types of cheeses (which are indeed delicious, but beets + cheese do not a £30 dinner make).The cocktails, on the other hand...are lethal...in the very best possible way. My whisky sour had me all but rolling on the floor, and it didn't even really taste boozy as I was drinking (read: guzzling) it. What a sneaky minx! I'd go back for that, alone, and maybe a plate or two of the sub £7 dishes. As others have said, book a million years in advance, unless you want to dine after midnight.

TyZkl664gRXoq9SbiUcOLQ.text: Ordered: Duck and Waffle, Cripsy Pig earsPrice: ~£25Review: The herd effect had a slightly larger impact on my view of Duck&Waffle. Not a bad place to eat, with a great view, but lets be serious here. Who eats an overpriced duck and waffle, and crispy pig ears for £25, and still feels ridiculously hungry afterwards. Am I the piggy or is it the portions? The Crispy Pig ears are fantastic - worth the taste FOR SURE. The Duck and Waffle itself - tasty, but really, is it really all that? I've tasted better in nyc for sure. Give Duck and Waffle a shot, but don't expect magical ducks and magical waffles :)

7lh5bsxjCqAXsXYFyQsPvw.text: The food was excellent and the signature dish (duck and waffle) were prepared perfectly. This was one of the best ducks I have ever eaten. The view from the window seats looked spectacular but we were seated in the center. Most of the window seats were for 2 people.What prevented the 5 star review for me was our experience with the 2 doormen the first time we arrived. When we inquired about eating there, we were informed rather coldly that advanced reservations would be required. I didn't mind being told about the reservations but the tone and demeanor was definitely not acceptable. We almost didn't book a reservation.

VMdJyTtcF-drFBnxAlYekw.text: 24 hours of panoramic London views and quixotic dishes: a big win for the City of London.I've been to Duck and Waffle several times now, both during "normal" hours of operation and late night adventures; the food is tasty and affordable and the servers are knowledgeable and polite. If you can get a table--and they aren't easy to pick up on short notice--make sure to try a number of the easy to share dishes. But, most importantly tuck into the eponymous signature plate, or two.Cocktails and wine are on the pricey end, so imbibing will lift you out of the reasonably affordable range to the questionably costly. Though, when you're atop the City you'll likely want to be toasting to high life.

E3v_IsEZlPyQSZmGcrD3uw.text: I'd heard so many good things about Duck & Waffle, so naturally I was super excited to try out the food!  Getting to the actual restaurant was pretty fun, the fastest elevator I've been on to get to the 40th floor, felt a bit like being in Willy Wonka's Glass Elevator!  And the views of London were absolutely stunning!  We were seated pretty quickly and I went for dinner in quite a large group, about 10 of us.  I was sat at the end of the table so it was easier for me to talk to the waiter on behalf of the group.  I took a look at the menu and asked whether we ordered lots of plates to share like tapas or a dish each.  This waiter was the rudest, snootiest man and literally sighed at me when I asked this question and just replied "If none of you have eaten here before it will just be best to tell you all when you're paying attention".  Wow.  Just wow.  I didn't think that was much a difficult question.  If I was rude myself I could understand his reaction, but I wasn't.  The waiter had ruined the excitement for me completely, but hey, he was serving us so I was still going to be British about it and be polite.We eventually ordered the food which took a fairly long time to come out.  To be completely honest, I wasn't that impressed.  The signature 'Duck and Waffle' was pretty darned good, but I found the rest of the food a bit meh.  This place definitely has it's attractions - quirky food, amazing views and a decent reputation.  I wasn't overly impressed though, I personally felt everything was a bit overpriced.  It was an experience to eat here but I don't think I'll be rushing back any time soon.

J-HwPhjfQwJY5AJPPdaWeA.text: Points to the good view of the restaurant for sure! Tried their star dish: duck and waffle, a bit of disappointed to be honest. The dish is quiet greasy and the menu is a bit simple and very little choice.

BQKPPfH5AcYKpHlr7ZFJWg.text: It's a bit of a posh place - you'll need to be dressed well enough to get past the guardians of the ground floor - but with a relaxed atmosphere. Naturally, you've got to get the duck & waffle. Now I'd always try out a signature dish (it's the best of the menu, right?) but in this case I'd keep going back for it no matter what. I admit, I was sceptical when I first heard of this upscale version of the southern comfort food, but damn they do it well here. The duck confit is all tender juicy flesh with crispy skin and the waffle is perfectly cooked with a sharp crunchy crust with a fluffy interior that drinks in the accompanying maple syrup. The combination of sweet waffle and savoury duck is a brilliant mix that I'd go for every time. And there is something about waffles that draws your inner child out to play and conjures up fond memories of Eggo toaster waffles.We also tried the crispy fried pig ears which are a great snack - something different for munching on while watching the game and I'm thinking I may make some for my next poker night. And while we're on alternative foods, I also had the dossant a couple of weeks ago when I ran the first cronut crawl. D&W's dossants look for all intents and purposes like deep fried croissants split in half and stuffed with fresh cream. And as far as I can tell, that's just what they are. £6 gets you a pair of small croissant-shaped flaky pastries with a fresh light and slightly lemony flavoured cream. A bit pricey, but then again D&W is a bit on the nicer side of things so not wholly unexpected.However, I think they are missing a beat here as while the croissant was represented in full, there was barely any soft fluffy doughnut in evidence. Really, Mr Doughnut has to take a look and wonder if that really is his kid...Granted, at this point we'd had more than our fair share of drinks but the bar is pretty hard to resist. I opted for a Sazerac which was perfectly balanced and deadly in potency. It's easy to drink, doesn't taste of booze (beyond the flavour of whiskey), and sweet enough to be moreish. A very dangerous yet delicious combination!At £17, the duck & waffle is a pricey option but worth it as a treat. The pig ears were £5 and an excellent value snack. I'll have to come back at a more reasonable time to test out the rest of the menu but all in all you are looking at something that's good for a treat once in a while but a bit too much for a regular stop. Unless of course you are a city boy/girl in which case I'm free to join you for dinner if you are paying!

UCGAT_q52y0OzubYHtXZzg.text: One of my favorite meals while in London and that means a lot coming from someone who loves to eat breakfast food! I easily made reservations online in advance of our visit as I know it's booked a ways out. Once we arrived we took the lift up to the 40th floor with great views the whole way up. At 9am it wasn't too busy so we got a great table near a window (but not next to it) and could move about easily to take photos. The food itself was great, just wish there was more of it (coming from an American who's used to large portions). My boyfriend had the banana ice cream waffle and a side of organic eggs which were also delicious.

Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Great views!
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Duck and Waffle dish was delicious!

rmU0md2AH1mYEE5SgQWChA.text: The reservation process was arduous and many mistakes were made but finally we had a reservation for 5 PM and we showed up at 4:45 PM the girl at the desk asked us to show proof of confirmation of our reservation and was very rude then shooed us off to the bar. 20 minutes later we checked in and our table was ready I wonder if she was ever going to come tell us we did get the best seat in the restaurant and the bacon wrapped figs were delicious as well as the garlic and rosemary bread and the staff at this point were fabulous the restaurant was still fairly empty as it was early but once it start to fill up it got worse the next two courses one of them being an ox doughnut that was delightful and a very simple mushroom and Parmesan ravioli that was arcticly Cold and tasted like a rubber shoe. My boyfriend who never ever complains who always says the food is delicious this time could not contain himself when the waiter asked why we hadn't finished the ravioli that later was very gracious and asked for his opinion which my boyfriend gave which is something we don't normally do because at that point there isn't really much to be done. My boyfriend goes to restaurants and is in the business and understands that mistakes are made and sometimes food goes out cold or taste bad and that's just what happens it's what happened after that that does not make me want to ever go back there again for the next 20 minutes I counted 15 staff members ignoring us not filling water not bringing us a check, not checking in we just wanted to leave the food was delicious and the beginning of the service was great but the end wasn't so great and we just wanted to leave and it was near impossible to get somebody to look our way to get a bill to pay for the food I don't think I go back unfortunately because of the way they handled at the end not because of the food. Restaurant send out bad food that just happens I don't blame them for that I do blame them for not paying attention to us we weren't being of noxious the waiter who would come to the table to ask about the ravioli really really wanted to know why we hadn't eaten it and in very short descriptive terms my boyfriend told him in a very nice way we weren't trying to be picky we weren't trying to get free food we were just honestly answering his question

DQIPxFpUcUfb3-2c6JEZtg.text: I came here for lunch on my last day in London and really enjoyed my meal here.  First off, if you're looking for a great view of London this is your spot.  It's situated on the 40th floor of the Heron Tower, right next to the Shard.  Sushi Samba is also in the same building but if you're in London may as well try more traditional British fare right?I think for dinner this place books up really quickly but I called the morning of for lunch and was able to get a window table for 2 at noon.  Granted, it was a weekday but it was still much easier than I had anticipated.My friend and I shared the special of the day - a beetroot and black pudding scotch egg, the mushroom small plate, and of course the restaurant's namesake the duck and waffle.  Among the two of us, three plates was just the right amount of full.  I thought the scotch egg was really well presented and had interesting flavors, so it's unfortunate that's not a regular item.  The mushroom was solid, but unfortunately the duck and waffle was just okay in my mind.  The duck was seasoned well, but the waffle was quite dry.This place isn't cheap, but you are paying for the views and experience, so I would still recommend it.  Lunch for 2 with 3 dishes and 2 coffees came to about 60 quid or 90 USD, but given the chance I would definitely revisit.  I hear they also serve breakfast which is perhaps more easily accessible if you are looking for a similar experience at a lower price point.

Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

ohVqy7DMis5Jdq4J9OUHbQ.text: AMAZING views, fun atmosphere and the food is great.The namesake Duck and Waffle dish was surprisingly tasty... would definitely recommend!

7okwadBWbPjL1LTCEGlZ3w.text: Outstanding.  Some really delicious combinations in a setting that allows panoramic views of one of the best cities on the globe.   BE AWARE!!!  This place is popular and reservations are a must.  We got LUCKY and a reservation cancelled just after we were turned away...we were trying to find another place to try when they let us know our table was ready...I will know better next time as it is not to be missed.  We'll be back!

kiCsd0BjPTxRdyCV_sMarQ.text: This was the best tasting food I have had in London this far. The food was amazing. I ordered the duck and waffle and I could have ordered three portions! It was seasoned extremely well, and the waffle was nice and fluffy. The atmosphere was really beautiful as it is in a high rise building in the middle of the city. The view was breathtaking. The service was delightful, and our waiter Max was outstanding. It's great for a date night or late night fancy eats. A definite must do in London

7XnLSuyrJ84PYF4-C9W5Vw.text: I've been meaning to post this review for aaagggessss!! I really liked Duck and Waffle! My partner and I went a while ago a it was his way of 'impressing me' as it was at the very beginning of our relationship. Needless to say, I was impressed! The decor was lavish and elegant and swanky - right up my street! We both had the signature 'Duck and Waffle' dish because let's face it, how can you not?!? I thought that it was great! Who knew that duck and waffle went so well together! And I love eggs so that was a bonus too! The staff were nice and attentive as well! I'd definitely go back there again!

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Duck and waffle!

idtKpaNyLCxd1nFew1U4JA.text: Out for brunch! Outstanding views and good food

iq5aXi8QQfTyZjWiH2PDvA.text: My friend had asked for a table by the window when she booked, when the booking was confirmed and when we called to say we were stuck in traffic so we were pretty excited to have a delightful booth overlooking east London. It's our friend's birthday! she yelled. I've been wanting to come here for 2 years, I screeched! The host looked suitably afraid at that point. But why worry? The view is incredible, the service is outstanding and everything I ate was also outstanding.We ordered 4 small plates: pollock meatballs with a sumptuous lobster cream, tasty bacon wrapped dates and spicy ox cheek doughnut and, the stand out for me, coal charred aubergine. I love aubergine and this is one of the best aubergine dishes I have ever had - the balance of the cumin and yoghurt was perfect.Next up was duck and waffle. This exceeded my expectations and should be obligatory to try. We also shared one tartiflette, especially decadent on my part because I'd had 1.5 Kappacasein cheese sandwiches for lunch (although we didn't eat till 10pm and want on a walk london Pepys/Wren tour in the meantime, so sue me). It had a much stronger flavour than other tartiflette I've tried - not in a bad way - and now on reviewing the menu I see this was due to the involvement of truffles. Ah, truffles. YES.By this time I was pretty drunk on whatever delicious tipple my Wine Society friend had been plying us with so entered Natalie-Luxe mode in which I start ordering whatever I want AND HANG THE EXPENSE. Turns out what I wanted was a pistachio macaroon with chocolate mousse, and a bacon & caramel Manhattan.The macaroon was impressively large, a little chewy for my tastes but the chocolate mousse was sublime. Also sublime was the cocktail, picked from an immensely appealing menu (Aqua Shard, take note). About the smoothest drink I've ever had with the salty bacon flavour perfectly off-setting the sweet caramel. Quality.It's pretty nice to go somewhere you have been excited about for a long time and find that it not only exceeds your expectations but blows them out of the water. I hope it wasn't just a fluke, because I would like to come back here again and again and enjoy the same amazing food and absolutely stellar service which was so attentive, friendly, helpful and efficient we must have remarked upon it at least a dozen times throughout the course of the evening.I was bracing myself for the bill but it came in somewhere around £65 which I was happy to pay for one of the best meals out I've had in ages. Duck & Waffle is as good as it gets, and gets my 500th review and five very shiny stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Bacon and caramel manhattan

mf8VzbFnGX68NZqR7yBeSg.text: Duck and Waffle is one of my favourite restaurants in the city! It's unique, with amazing views, good service, great drinks and brilliant food!The Menu is great, as one I first looked at it I thought 'What the hell is this', but when we got there and I began working my way through it, everything I had was lovely! The highlights include...Bacon wrapped dates-We thought 'why not' when we ordered these, but they were so good we ordered some more with our mains!Crispy Pigs Ears-Get one, share the bag, great to snack on whilst you wait/talk and enjoyNduja bread...this is one of the best things of all time, again we ordered another one later on as this one was demolished pretty quickly. it's like soft pizza dough with a spicy (Nduja) sauce, and it's just amazing. Then we get to the small plates...all of these are really good, but our favourites include the Octopus and Chorizo, Meatball and Beef Tatare. Hands down the best thing on this list is the Ox Cheek Doughnut...it's so wrong but tastes so right!For the table...it's got to be the duck and waffle! The duck is sometimes a little dry, but this dish is still great. One between two is about right! I would focus on the small plates, and then maybe just 1 or 2 at a push of the larger ones. Try as much as you can and take in the stunning views whilst you do it.Drinks wise, I am ashamed to admit...it's all about the Roasted Cosmo!Enjoy!

89lLitH14x5W2ad_fWJGzA.text: I hate when people misjudge you.   I was sober, yet tired and not looking fancy.  I was showing my gal around London, went to London's Burn festival, met these fellows, and we meant to come here for the late crescendo, since most other places were closed...this dumb place called Duck waffle.  We walked up after two hookers were allowed in the door.  The guy with us did the talking; the doorman said, "One of us was too intoxicated" to get in the door.  We unfortunately asked who, and I was the culprit... they apparently have never been intoxicated, drunk, inebriated, or sober to know the difference, most likely just your average stupid.  Anyway, I recommend walking up to Great Eastern Street to a joint on the left as you come around the corner for some solid late evening food if you are hungry.  And trust me, I am not one to give two thoughts about strict door policy; it was the mass misinterpretation and insulting situation.  Duck Waffle is as dumb as it sounds.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Don't bother coming here.
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Want to be fancy... Trash.

IHD-j_bpDy7c9RoumgitGQ.text: Make a reservation or come during an off time. We came in the middle of the afternoon without a reservation and waited around 2 hours. The food was good but nothing too mind blowing. The view of London from the restaurant however is stunning on a clear day!

yuNetFXENbLsaBLUMSaznw.text: After hearing so much about this place, I was dying to come here! I ended up heading here with some friends after a night out at about 3 a.m., and there was a short queue (about 15 minutes) to get in. Duck & Waffle is open 24/7 so if you didn't make a reservation I recommend going late at night or super early for breakfast at sunrise! Once you enter the building, you get on a reaallly fast lift that takes you directly up to the restaurant, which is on the 40th floor. The decor is an eclectic and interesting mix of old and new: blue and white tiles in the entrance, a cluster of posh chandeliers hanging over the staircase, and some modern urban artwork around the bar area. Of course, what really makes the restaurant spectacular is its view of the city, and most notably the bullet building. We sat at a table next to floor to ceiling windows and it took me a minute to get used to the height! I ordered a savory dish and a sweet dish - the duck egg with truffles and toast soldiers and the banana dessert waffles. The food was amazing and if it hadn't been 4 a.m. I would've wanted to stay for hours ordering everything on the menu! Also, the prices were fairly reasonable! Most dishes were around £10 to £20. The only downside to my experience here was that the bar had just closed so I didn't get to try any of their famous cocktails. Next time I'm in London, I will definitely be back!

M0BBNPlGkgo11rCPiv2MJw.text: Unfortunately, the view is about the only thing I liked about this restaurant. I personally would only come here for drinks and late nights going forward. My friend and I both had the Duck & Waffle, the duck was just ok, lacked little in flavor. The customer service is pretty awesome (hence the 3 stars). The interior in the dining area doesn't quite match the beautiful views of this restaurant. I was so excited to try this place!!

nDo5eGKNN2hmfJhmRzuqmw.text: I went there for lunch on a Tuesday with a friend (we had to make the reservation 2 weeks in advance) and we tried to order as many dishes as possible. All of them were really great. The duck and waffle didn't let me down. I thought it would be a weird combination but I really liked it. However, the best dish was actually one of their specials for that day, a French tartiflette with truffles. I was not very light but it was really, really good.The waiters were really attentive and nice, making good suggestions when asked. The service was also very fast. They have a cozy and modern ambiance. We got a table in a wonderful place, surrounded by the amazing view up there. I can't think of anything bad to say, so I just have to give them 5 stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Meatballs with lobster sauce, bread with artichoke and Parmesan, and octopus
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

cbJBOMO0S-_7rWAlzceRwQ.text: Maybe I'm easily pleased, but even the glass lift ride up to the Duck and Waffle was a treat. Watching London simultaneously fade away beneath your feet and open up as your view expands across the whole city is something really special. As we arrived at floor 40 it felt like we'd turned the wrong way somewhere. We hadn't. You do just have to walk past the toilets to get to the restaurant. We were seated straight away. You know that feeling where you're mentally counting off where they could sit you?  As the waiter kept walking I began to hope we were going to get the corner table. I internally leaped for joy as he stopped there, giving us views on two sides, one down onto the gherkin and one across east London to where I live. Perfect. The menu was a little confusing and although we were offered guidance we were far too British to actually accept it. There were sides, "for the table", and small plates. We decided to buy a mixture of things and share which is easy for a couple but might make things a bit harder in a group. The ox cheek donut smelt warm and comforting, and was my boyfriend's favourite part of the meal. I preferred the lamb, which was dry and crunchy, served in strips, with a gooseberry sauce. We also had the duck and waffle which was nice but the waffle was a little dry for me, though the duck was sweet and sublime. For dessert we went for the baked Alaska. I was excited because I've never had a real one of these and a little disappointed when they cheated by serving ice cream coated in American marshmallow fluff. One day I'll find an authentic one! Including service and a cocktail each the bill came to £100.Despite a few little niggles, eating at the Duck and Waffle was absolutely worth the extra cost and effort making a reservation. Indeed, we've decided to cut down on our Byron habit so we can save up to eat here again!

ZrKXRMiY84FxxccVkuf2XQ.text: I knew from reading the reviews that the food wasn't all that great but the views were good. The only thing that was okay was the duck and the cheeseball. Ordered the pig ears, was very salty not tasty. The views? Is that best London has to offer? Guess I'm spoiled coming from NYC

ACuLlYBVyXBzn7AafEv7IA.text: What can I say, this is the first time I eat on the top floor of a new-ish skyscraper and am surprised at how small the bill is. It's always been the other way around. Duck & Waffle needs no introduction at this point, so I'll just review it to stick it on my "to visit" list for anybody I can send my reviews to. It's modern fusion cooking with a magnificent mostly-all-around view, and years after the launch it is still packed on weekdays. Only minor downside is the hard surfaces everywhere in the room make it very echo-prone and loud. This is perhaps by design to allow the numerous bankers to conduct their affairs in peace but a few carpets here and there might attenuate the whole thing below uncomfortable levels.Friendly competent service as can be expected. Fast, too, since they need that table turnaround for volume considering their price point.The dress code does not seem to be enforced as numerous patrons wore trainers and aside from aforementioned bankers most men also wore collarless shirts or T-shirts.

NnJTAq1c6vLOyKl8OjBm9Q.text: Great experience. Highly recommend the duck & waffles and the bacon wrapped dates! Great view if you are near a clear window. Mixed drinks were perfect!

-B1S_e4jpm4hMdoxJLvG6Q.text: All I have to say is what a view!! I had mistakenly booked a reservation one month ago for 745am vs pm ( my bad) and they still were kind enough to seat us. A must have is the steak tartar and the duck and waffle! I ve never had an AMAZING steak tartar but this was melt in your mouth steak tartar. The duck and waffle was the best I've ever had. The view is absolutely spectacular. This is a must do in London.

yocpW6E23FEzH3z5XSjLZw.text: Walked in and snagged a seat in the bar area right against the window for a magnificent view 40 stories up. Had the Apple Pie & Rye cocktail, which was inventive like crazy as it was served as a clear liquid with a cucumber slice...but was made of rye and tasted like apples. Here's the description per the menu:"Clarified rye whiskey, St. Germain, distilled apple pie, cucumber bitters. Carbonated."Wow. So, anyway...For food I had the Bacon-wrapped date (tremendous...shoulda gotten 2), the Toffee Apple Waffle (hot damn), and some famous bbq-spiced crispy pigs ears. Those came out smelling real nice and were good on the first bite but honestly the texture just didn't do it for me after that. Still, I brought the bag home with the leftovers and will end up finishing them during my week in London. Not wanting the meal to end, I extended the meal with a special treat - a pour of the going-extinct Hibiki 17 Year Japanese whisky. It was pricy, but may be my only chance to drink that in my lifetime. It was also a decent size pour (2 shots), and may be the only dime I spend on food my entire time in London. So pretty easy to justify!So I know reservations are nearly impossible to get here, but give it a try on an off-hour (like 9:30pm Sunday night) and you'll definitely be able to get a seat in the bar area as groups make their way to the dining room. The bar menu isn't the largest, but has enough to get a feel for the place in a more informal way.

Uu-1gvImvaiLPSOBFoJeGw.text: The only meal worth going is their one special. Be ready to feel like outsider if you are the only vegetarian in your company.

OJCxwkRLIYMJCYo3upw75A.text: On our trip to London this was a must stop. We made reservations and went in the late evening. The elevator ride up is a quick one with pretty great views of the city. Even though we were on time for our reservation they said our table wasn't ready and sat us in the bar for drinks.In my opinion, even though the bar was a really cool spot, it was a ploy to get us to spend more money on specialty drinks.We were then taken to our table and they took our coats and hung them.  The seats allowed us to see views of the entire city, which were fantastic. Drinks were amazing, and the food was even better. My favorite thing we ordered was actually the duck and waffle. The waffle And duck were so crispy and delicious it kept you going back for more.

9qClWT0hoSaJOoiPw4rUoQ.text: Like the name suggests, Duck and Waffle is famous for one dish - Duck & Waffle. Looking at the menu, it was on the pricey side ($34 NZD), so I went for the Porridge with maple pecans, toasted seeds and banana and a pot of English Breakfast tea, while my Mum ordered the Poached Eggs on Sourdough Toast with hand churned butter. I loved the presentation of the Porridge and it tasted heavenly.But, the best part about dining at Duck and Waffle? The view. Located in the Heron Tower (one of the largest buildings in London) and situated on the 40th floor, the views from where you sit are incredible.   Duck and Waffle is one of those places I would visit just for the experience - dining up high, looking out over the spectacular views. However, next time, I would come back for a morning coffee or a drink after work, as I believe it is too pricey for what it is worth.

bjhlABB8fG-J4OPGPEv2iA.text: Overhyped, but if you come with moderate expectations of decent food and a good view, you'll be glad you made the visit. Arriving, I was surprised to have to walk down a dark hall past the restrooms to get to the host--and then that the host asked our party to wait more than fifteen minutes for a reserved table (offering neither bar seats nor an apology). Once seated, we noticed several empty tables that could easily have held our group, none of which were ever seated during the hour or two while we ate. As for the food, the eponymous dish is pricey and unremarkable. But I'd return for the gooey bacon- wrapped dates or the fresh burrata--though it's hard to get either of those wrong.

21bS_cqyvW5ZLi4A1JZRxg.text: Made reservations to come here on our trip to London. Our friend recommended this place for their food. And since it's on the 40th floor of a building near the Shard, we figured this is actually a better value than paying to go up to the Shard because we will also get to enjoy a meal here!Once you get to the restaurant, you are kindly asked to wait at the bar/ waiting area where you can grab a drink and start enjoying the view while they get your table ready. We enjoyed the view of London and took a couple snaps before we entered the dining area. We didn't get a table by the window as they were already all taken, but we got seated as close as we can and were still able to enjoy the view. We both ordered the duck and waffles...well since the restaurant is called duck and waffles, this would probably be the item to order and we were right! The duck leg was juicy and tender which was a nice surprise and complimented the waffles perfectly! My boyfriend was impressed with the meal I planned. Before we left, one of the tables by the window opened up and we were able to grab a quick snap at that table before heading out. Staff were friendly. Overall great experience and I would recommend it to anyone visiting London and wants a good meal with a good view!

FPC_SQcuXZaQsgyTjAXEcw.text: Everything here was wow. Definitely some of the best food I've ever had. My boyfriend and I went here for our first meal in London and we were not disappointed. We ordered three things: the tartar, the rabbit dish, and obviously the signature Duck and Waffle dish.Tip: don't forget to bring your id because they id you at the building entrance Reservation: necessaryAesthetics:The decor for the restaurant was classy/fancy. We were lucky to get a table by the window. From there you can see a view of London.Service: We were running late by 30 minutes but they were professional and hospitable and still took us to our seat. They didn't rush us at all. Make sure to be courteous though and call to let them know.Wine & Dine: I've only had tartar one other time so I'm not an expert but if I had to describe the tartar here it didn't feel weird or slimy that I was eating raw meat. The meat was seasoned well. My boyfriend in particular really enjoyed the rabbit. Some parts of it were bitter and he liked it. If you're into that I'd recommend it. My personal favorite and to die for was the duck and waffle. I could go on and on about this dish. I was almost sad that I had to share it. The syrup was what especially made the dish amazing. I'm pretty sure they made it there I've never had syrup like it!

0TTSY_nBHpUeruUlu6nU5A.text: Massively overrated, but I'd recommend coming here if the view is what you're after. Located on the 40th floor, Duck and Waffle provides one of the best views of London for dining.Reservations seem to book up pretty quickly, as it was all full when I looked about 2 weeks in advance. However, my credit card company was easily able to make a reservation on my behalf for lunch, as well as request a window seat for the best view. My friend and I arrived at about 12:50pm, 10 minutes early for our reservation. They asked us to wait at the bar area and provided us a drink menu. I considered getting a drink but this month all their special cocktails featured vegetables and I HATE VEGETALS so no thanks. We stood around for about 15 minutes, and at 1:07 I asked if the table was ready yet. The person responded with an incredulous "no?!?!!?". Of course I was surprised, as the reservation was for 1pm, so you would exactly the table to be ready at 1, not 1:09. For a restaurant that obsesses over time (they give you approximately a 90 minute time interval for your time at the dining table), you'd think the table would be ready on time. Maybe it was because we weren't dressed in suits like many of the business people lunching here (their dress code is "smart casual" which as you know means nothing), but I respected their wishes by not wearing shorts, and had a button down on.Anyway, we were eventually lead to our window side table, and the view was... ok. Not exactly sure what you're supposed to be looking for in the London skyline, but I do admit there is a charm in dining hundreds of feet in the air, and the view of the buildings is kinda cool (def better than looking into a street of traffic for sure!).We opted for the ox cheek doughnut, the brûlée foie gras, and the croquettes. The ox cheek doughnut was pretty pleasant, and it was fun to split it open to review the steaming hot ox cheek inside. It paired nicely with the sauce underneath, but I do think the crust of the doughnut was a tad bit too sweet from the sugar. The foie gras was my least favorite dish. It was yet another play on sweet and savory, but it fell short on the savory side. It was hard to taste the foie through the caramelization on top. The bread that came with it was delicious, but again, the sweetness of the bread overwhelmed the savoriness and richness of the foie. If you didn't tell me there was foie, I would be convinced it was just egg!The croquettes were really nice - super crispy and fluffy on the inside, and the cream it sat on complemented the flavors, while also cutting through the deep fried ball. I highly recommend a few of these per person.We both opted to get the duck and waffle as it is their signature dish. I decided to try the green tea pairing with the waffle. At £6 it's quite expensive, but I did get a whole pot of tea with it. The tea itself was okay, but it wasn't a good quality green tea. As for how it PAIRED with the duck and waffle was completely lost on me. I guess they wanted a bitter tea to contrast with the again sweet and savory duck and waffle but it didn't really work. The duck itself was nicely cooked, and had a great sear on the skin. It fell off the bone, and the meat was super tender and juicy. The waffle itself was okay- it's a bit on the harder side, but it's necessary to soak up the syrup without falling apart. While the fried duck egg was a nice touch , I don't think it actually did anything for the dish in terms of flavor or texture. I love popping yolks as much as anyone else but the dish as the whole just didn't come together well. Individually they are all very good, but I feel that Duck and Waffle is trying too hard with these sweet and savory pairings and they're just not working out. What was most disappointing about the entire experience was the cold service we received. Based on other yelp reviews, it seems like it really depends on who your servers are, and maybe how well you dress. The biggest travesty of the meal was that they automatically added a "DISCRETIONARY 12.5% service charge". I quickly looked through other reviews, and it seems to be a common occurrence. How is it a DISCRETIONARY charge of they automatically add it in without telling you?!? Is it based on THEIR DISCRETION? I flagged down someone to remove the charge, and they did so without complaint, but we were met with even colder service afterwards (they threw the new bill on the table without saying a word). Considering tipping is not even customary in London, I'm not sure if they do it because foreigners might not be aware of this, and blindly pay without checking the bill. Overall, while the food was decent, and the view was nice, the shady service charge added on was highly disappointing. Yes, this is a great place for a date or a celebration meal, but I don't think anyone should come here regularly. The view is nice, but not worth the high prices (our meal came out to £77 which is quite a lot for lunch IMO).

PAXRSk0lLqD1TOgQK8_dYg.text: One of the worst experiences I've ever had. Ruined my trip to London, incredibly racist staff.I was visiting a buddy of mine for the weekend and he recommended that since we would be out very late we get a reservation at Duck & Waffle for a late night bite. He said his parents went there all the time and told him the food was great. We made a reservation for 2:30 AM, not a typo, but the place is open 24/7 so it isn't out of the ordinary. When we got to the restaurant we saw a long line waiting to get inside. After talking to the lady in front of us we realized that this was the line for non-reservation guests only. So we went to the front of the line to talk to the bouncer, who was letting people into and out of the restaurant. This is where our night goes completely downhill. The bouncer we encountered was incredibly rude and unprofessional. When we asked him if we could go inside as we had a reservation he refused and asked to see it. Fair enough. Unfortunately, it was buried in my friend's email inbox so we had to step aside and look for it. As we were looking we overhead the bouncer tell one of his coworkers that we were probably just making it up and just trying to cut the line. I confronted him and said, "I heard what you just said. Trust me , we have a reservation..." The bouncer doesn't reply, just stares at me. My friend finally finds the reservation, and when we go to show the bouncer he refuses to let us in! He claimed we were acting too intoxicated (this is while the people in line were clearly very intoxicated). We ask to see a manager. He reluctantly calls him down, and says to us that the manager is just going to tell you the same thing I told you. We argue with the manager who tells us if the bouncer says you are too intoxicated you can't come up and that is final. After arguing with him for what felt like 10 minutes, he ultimately lets us go through, but says we can't order any alcoholic drinks when we get upstairs. My friend and I, outraged at this point, but still hungry, agree. When we get upstairs we are greeted with nothing less than complete commotion. It seemed like everyone in the restaurant was belligerently drunk. Guests were knocking down glasses, yelling at each other, food was spilled all over the tables, etc. After being seated we call over the manager again to discuss how we were being treated by the establishment. Particularly,  how unprofessional it was to deny us entry or drinks because we were "too intoxicated" when we were clearly coherent enough to find a reservation, and calmly argue  our situation with him and the bouncer downstairs, not to mention the behavior of the other guests who were evidently more intoxicated than us. Obviously we were very upset, but instead of trying to accommodate us the manager tells the bouncers to "Come over and escort these two gentlemen out." At this point, we are just stunned.As the security guards come over we told the Manager that we felt targeted and their establishment's treatment of us was nothing short of racist, (as both my friend and I are Indian, whereas most other guests were white and female). I guess that was the magic word, because he told the bouncers to "stand down" and finally tried to have an open dialogue with us. Ultimately, after a 15 minute discuss he realized his mistakes and told us the bouncer downstairs would be spoken too. He offered to comp us the meal and make us any drink we wanted stating that it was clear to him now that "we weren't intoxicated at all." We denied both... Paid the full amount and told him that we won't be coming back and neither would my friend's parents.

POvEHRaBv7asvxjzSHL7xA.text: Food is good, view is amazing, service is OK. Me and my friend were here in a summer morning for breakfast, we ordered the featured duck and waffle. Meat was great, waffle was soft and in the same time a bit crispy. The orange juice here is amazing, I highly recommend it. Latte was good as well. The waiter served our table was not quite himself though, he must had been drinking too much the night before.

VCcEUeEV27oarah-S77skg.text: Rude. Food wasnt great. Homie had a reservations but they didnt let him in. Never comimg back here.

bugln7D7y13bXZBALFqrlg.text: Duck and WaffleI went to this restaurant at high noon as I knew it would be pretty amazing.  The day was clear of clouds and the restaurant is perched on the 40th floor of the Herons Tower in the financial district in the City of London.  Using the tube to get there and exiting at the Liverpool Street.  Really this place has it all in that it is well situated in City of London and its open 24/7.  Which makes it a great if you choose to visit some of the oldest pubs in City of London such as The Hoop and Grape and find yourself craving some midnight snacks.  The name is in the restaurant.  Duck and Waffle specializes in this dish but also has plenty of other options that can appeal to many palettes.  Fresh baked breads are a must if you love carbs.  It comes out nice piping out from the oven and a great opinion if you get the English Burrata.  Other starters that I recommend from the snacks and small plates that I felt are a must are the bacon wrapped dates and smoked eel.  If you love bacon then these dates are to die for...one is not enough for one person maybe three is a good number to start for one person.  Crispy bacon on the outside stuffed with Portuguese sausage linguiça and one of my favorite cheese Manchego make such a perfect bite.  The smoked eel I say is a must as if you love smoked fishes.  The UK and other neighboring Scandinavian countries do smoked fish the best as this art of preserving foods has been going on for centuries.  Each bite of eel is brightened up with creme fracihe. You will need to get the Duck and Waffle dish if you have come this far to eat at Duck and Waffle.  At least have someone in your party should get it and may have it in there desire to share.  It has the perfectly crispy cooked duck leg and thigh served over warm crunchy waffle with a fried duck egg to cut open as you devour each bite.  If you like sweetness a maple syrup is served on the side for the drizzling adventure.  Duck and Waffle of course offers much more but these are my recommendations.  They have a full bar with creative cocktails.  My favorite which was the Red Pepper Spritz as it was refreshing on a hot day with a very good flavor of red bell pepper.  One other note about this restaurant you cannot wear any hats in the building and you take a separate elevator that is located in front of the Heron Tower to get to Duck and Waffle.  You cannot miss it from the street.

ybNZs9gMESAfFXS2J-bnBg.text: To be clear - i would give the atmosphere 5 stars.. but over all i say it was A OK! Duck and waffle was a really special place to go to for our first night In London. I was exited about the fabulous and hip decor and of course anyone would love that 360 view of the city. We went for their late night and we all got our own entree. Some things to know....  get the pork apple corn dog. Or maybe get 5. It was my favorite. Delicious!- the ox tail donut was a little too unique for our taste - The elevator is Trippy cool - Fries were MEH
