m22uWC02gvgdJe9QXI3A9A.text: The experience to have in London after partying in Shoreditch!We went there with friends without booking around 2am, after spending the evening in Shoreditch.The place is really fancy and beautiful. You will have a wonderful view of London.We all took the duck and waffle. It was delicious. The duck was well cooked and it was a great match with the waffle (and maple syrup). £18 for it is a bit pricy but you pay for the food quality and the view.I think it is a place to go at least once, to have a great view of London with good food

Vh19j4ylxR0CZh0aKNXA_w.text: The best aspects of Duck & Waffle are the colorful elevator ride, the view from the restaurant, and the amazing staff at the bar. I had an excellent old fashioned while friends enjoyed other mixed drinks. The food was okay. Not fantastic for the price of the experience, but okay. Friends agreed that the best entree was the duck and waffles, as it ought to be. We also tried the octopus, beef tartare, roasted cauliflower, polenta bites, burrata ravioli and maple-glazed cornbread. The beef tartare was sliced thin, rather than minced, which didn't appeal to our group. I didn't care for the ravioli with burrata and marjoram with artichokes, watercress and hazelnuts. And the polenta bites were pretty bland. I did like the cornbread with an ample amount of diced jalapeño, the sweet glaze and harissa yogurt. It was a good combination of spicy-sweet-savory. But I probably would not come back for cornbread. An old fashioned, maybe!

kRliLVnS-LvDWCpl-kyDcg.text: Book a table (a month in advance) just before sunset and ask to sit by the window - you won't be disappointed. The signature Duck and Waffle dish is a must.

o2z0f26_OxWOSq9Xyjt6XA.text: This is definitely on my to-do list the next time I'm back in London. The view is spectacular so be sure to make a reservation. The duck and waffle is a must, but everyone at our table had something good.

UdKXkqaTmtJrLblGwBREPQ.text: Amazing view, delicious house-baked breads and high quality dishes but not sure it's worth the hype or the wait. Cocktails are pricey and adventurous but not all hits. Service isn't quite up to snuff. The elevator ride was my favourite part. This place is worth a try but I won't be rushing back.

qjuxVNz6gycpNB7Yqa9kKQ.text: What a lovely experience!We went for Sunday Brunch and were very lucky with the weather. Could see all the way to Wembley Stadium! The ride up is quite something (look to the right of the main entrance). You step into a glass elevator on the outside of the building and shoot up to the 40th floor quick enough to make your ears pop. A word of advice, go left out of the lift - not right and into the janitor's cupboard as I did!You should walk into the bar area (where you can have a coffee/cocktail if you're not eating) and then into the restaurant proper. We were there on a Sunday morning so there were more families, couples etc than bankers and so the atmosphere was quite fun an relaxed. The waiting stuff were fun, attentive and quick. We ordered a plate of stuffed dates to share and then a duck & waffle and ox cheek eggs benedict both were superb (although part of me wanted to pig out and have the full english).One set of eggs were fried, the other poached and both were perfect. The salt v sweet, soft v crunchy contrat of the duck and waffle was definitely the best of the two dishes. Although the hollandaise a beef combo ran it close. As we're not alcoholics, there was no drinking and the result was a very reasonable £40 for 2 people. Not the sort of thing you'd do every week but a great place to impress out of toweners/parents/girfriend or a little treat.

P9Y9LQ0ZiLLPzL0KkXd3BA.text: Im not sure how? but the fact this place was 40 storeys high had passed me by?! So the lift up which is open sided was a pretty cool treat.The venue itself is very nice looking, but obviously takes 2nd place to the amazing view, if your scared of heights though I recommend a central restaurant seat. The choices available are decent but you definitely need to choose correctly.  In our group there were 4 dishes. I had the roast sausage which was good but didnt blow me away. One of us went for the fois gras, extremely rich so the generous portion was a bit too much. I did manage to try the hash browns as an additional and would definitely recommend them, very tasty! overall the food was good, and reasonably priced... but if you brunching for food instead of the view there are better places.The service was attentive and friendly and I would definitely come back.

yBnxOfF4dBUT0p-EaGMvXw.text: The food was decent and it's a great view of the city. But the service UNACCEPTABLE. NEVER have I been treated so poorly. When I arrived at Duck & Waffle, it was 3:15am and I was inarguably sober. I had not been drinking that evening. However when they asked for ID, I handed mine to my friend to pass along. They took this to mean I was wasted past an acceptable level. Ridiculous. And they refused to let us into the restaurant. We ended up waiting in the cold for over an hour and weren't let into the restaurant until 4:30. My friends and i have been set on coming to this place for a while and drove all the way into the city to eat here, so we didn't want to just turn around and go home.But moral of the story, is the guards downstairs have wayyyy too much power and use it against you because they can... Totally ruins the restaurant for the rest of the night. And when we spoke to the manager about it she really didn't seem to give a crap.

ygVGoRPGKdqgNOlLMP0HBg.text: Breakfast with a phenomenal view of London! I went here with a girlfriend and our only regret was not calling in to make a reservation as that would have garnered us window seats. The duck and waffle is great, the waiters are nice... and the view speaks for itself.

GPghVYUNTXJLUWjD4Q-bgA.text: Overpriced, miniscule portions with food combinations that try too hard to be innovative and unique that they just end up confusing your palate and making you feel ill. The crispy duck had barely any meat on it and was fried to the likes of KFC, the mustard seeded maple syrup was sickening and the waffle was rock hard as if it had been reheated too long. Our wines arrived halfway through the meal despite multiple reminders so unfortunately couldn't even wash it down. The foie gras creme brulee with lobster on top was one to try but unfortunately another disappointment as it tasted too sweet and all wrong with the consistency of a melted parfait. The views are stunning but I won't be returning anytime soon.

OMgpjW6S59LG3D0UoAKuFg.text: A little apprehensive to go, as I wash;t sure I would enjoy the food but I was happily surprised. I enjoy it a lot.Going here is about much more than the just the food. The general experience is one to be remembered with amazing views and quirky aspects, it really was an incredible experience.It's definitely a place to try when you're visiting London!!!

0gWbU5OBJwbyLHyGLBzdBw.text: I wasn't sure about this first of all but it actually works really well. Duck and waffle with maple syrup seemed like an odd combination but it was lovely and the restaurant itself is beautiful

VQTsJi-1gDCx6E_sydnAbQ.text: Impressive location, great views of London and awesome Duck & Waffle dish...Can't wait to check in again!!!

LMUjECStMfTRZDV4qydEUw.text: Best view in town (glass elevator not for the faint hearted/afraid of heights type) the food is great. The service was a bit over the top we had about 3 different people come over in the first 5 mins to ask if we were ready to order which I always find irritating. We had an early sat night booking 5:30pm so once it got busier they eventually left us well alone - not really a happy medium. The food is great, my highlights: the squid & chorizo plus nduja and cheese bread sharing plates were absolutely delicious. It is very pricy for what it is but the setting does make up for it. I wouldn't go all the time but everyone should experience it once and ideal for a special occasion. The Duck and Waffle dish just works!

-xog9B_vLcC50S7y6MehFw.text: I thought the food was great, but the service was terrible. We had this really pretentious girl who was extremely rude. Was it because we were from out of town? Maybe. Enjoyed the experience and would come back, as long as I get better service.

P-hTkdI-uXfg3R6s49JChg.text: The views are amazing from this restaurant, if you are coming here to impress then choose a spot by the window. I thought the duck was very greasy and fatty, I would say it was ok, but the all day breakfast was a winner with me. The service was attentive and the staff took the time to explain what the dishes were and the specials of the day.A very good experience, the views was what impressed me the most if it wasn't for that then I probably wouldn't have come here.

ipBJrf2XH_aNSXYd3fQXzw.text: Incredible views. We tried to get in for a drink and the doorman said to come back in about 30 mins, pessimistically I thought we'd come back and still not be let in... well I was wrong and they were totally true to their word. I'll definitely be coming back.

mC8z7GHb6odYI8RuwdY12A.text: Nearby Tower 42's restaurant and champagne bar, catering for a similar chi-chi clientele, is on the 24th floor of that building; the BTTower's restaurant is on the 34th floor of that building and when called the Post Office Tower was open to the public I recall; this just opened European restaurant is on the 40th floor of the newly built glassy Heron Tower, and is now the highest restaurant in London and yet is open to the public, along with it's interesting sister Japanese-Brazilian fusion restaurant on the 39th floor, and their shared Sky Bar which is on both floors linked by a transparent orange staircase! It's pretty much the height of business-chic, haha.The decor is smart and groovy and the service is friendly and efficient but the views are TRULY outstanding, especially at and after dusk. In fact, in my opinion, the vista from the west-facing bars is best, taking in all the tall and old City buildings and St Pauls Cathedral. Arguably, the restaurant and bar should have been swapped around, and this must surely be the first time for Qype that such an architectural criticism is a reason for giving a restaurant 4 and not 5 out of 5 stars?! If there was a 4.5, maybe I'd have given that  due to the lovely view of the river and Tower Bridge from the south side of this restaurant! The food? It is an interesting 4 star maybe for a surprising though creative combo menu. Small plates make it seem even reasonable, such as the tasty English smoked haddock scotch egg with curried mayo for £6 and crab on toast for £10, but they soon mount up to a nice-sized bill, however, especially if washed down by £12+ cocktails before, and £25+ wine from during and a £10 single brandy after. I wondered how the whole roast chicken for £25 and desert menu would have worked into the mix, but the size of our wallets, and the fact that it was already after midnight on a school night put a full stop to that!

cHZjPqwq3B2LErGdXmCmKQ.text: LOVED this restaurant! Went for a late (3:00) lunch, was seated by the window (although any table in the restaurant would have a stunning view of the city), and ate until my hearts content! I have a gluten allergy and the restaurant was very accommodating and my server was knowledgable about all the dishes. My girlfriend got the bread that was covered in sweet onions and cheese and she said it was amazing. We were able to share everything else: the mozzarella, the summer vegetables, and they even have a gluten free version of their signature dish: the duck and waffle. Soooo good!

1i9uBQIq3sqREC5oZBpadQ.text: The duck and waffle dish is definitely worth it! The duck is cooked perfectly. I took my family visiting from overseas here and they enjoyed the food, service and view. We tried a few different items on the menu, all are delicious but the duck and waffle was the favourite.

X2A-5H_msnTWaQERQDL2Xw.text: I've only been here for drinks, so I can't say anything about the food.  The atmosphere is buzzing and there is a good vibe.  I do look forward to going back and trying their menu!

0I6NboJrgNZZrgAw2nC61w.text: It is a definitely must-go because of the impressive view and the whole experience that you get by having a meal/drink so high in the sky. The food is really good, especially the signature Duck & Waffle waffle and the Elvis Waffle. However, it is the location of the place which makes it so attractive. Plus, it is open 24 hours which makes it accessible for every occasion.

oa3SGvinDBVe4WZJLCccvw.text: Loved everything. The view, the service & the food. Dont think of ordering anything other than the infamous "Duck and waffle" The duck is so crispy and flavorful, the egg was just right and the waffle was fluffy enough and not dry as some waffles are. Big yum!

4yjioz5zdn7nqFRW2I7zJg.text: I really want to give it a higher rating... I really do. I went in a group of 4 and everyone hated their food. I'm only giving it 2 stars because the view is amazing. If anything, this would be a good bar spot. Def don't go for the food

37MPmGPGpSO_k-ABU-r5zw.text: Yummy food and amazing view! The duck is perfectly crisp. The duck, waffle, egg and syrup all make a tasty mouth watering dish. However, it's pricey and the portion is relatively small compared to the price. I can see why there is such a hype. Definitely make sure to make a reservation!

V48j0Wgowecn1hfOJjkszg.text: Cannot believe how hard it was to book here, but eventually got there and here is my review. We got there a bit early, as I want to have a few drinks and enjoy the bar before eating. What a great move, checked out the bar on the sushisamba level which is on two floors, then went up one more floor to enjoy drinks at duck and waffles bar. * duck and waffle bar is quieter.  you don't have to book to go to these bars, so they get really busy, people in and out, scrambling for every space or seat to be near the window. It is an amazing view though. The drinks was on another level. Great drinks menu.  Duck waffle the venue was superb, high up in the sky with the view over London. Can't beat that. Couple tables are situated around the windows, and larger tables in the middle. Service was exceptional, really prompt and friendly. The food is made for sharing mostly. And its unique and very different. Weird mixture of flavours, to be honest some worked well and some didn't. But it was truly a good experience, never felt rushed and had a good time.

LMMwrKKTNvbijOBFdPAbHg.text: Before you read this, just know that I'm a tourist... so my view is skewed. D&W really reminded me of the City Club on Bunker Hill in Los Angeles... but the crowd and atmosphere here was much more casual.This was one of my favorite meals in London. Duck & Waffles is located on the very top floor of this noticeably tall black building (which i'm sure has a name ). The venue was gorgeous and view was already worth whatever price that D&W would charge. My partner and I splurged on this dinner and ordered as much as our hearts desired. Of course we got their signature D&W... which puts Roscoe's Chicken & Waffles to shame. The big piece of duck meat simply fell off the bone and it was the perfect kind of combination. We didn't expect to use the entire syrup bottle... but we did, and it was worth the calories. We also ordered a side of grilled octopus, ox-cheek donuts, foie gras creme brulee. We had the right amount and it surprisingly made us full. The Foie Gras creme burlee was an interesting dish. Who would have known that creme burlee can also be savory? The Ox-Cheek donut is a huge fried ball. It was kind of boring compared to the other dishes, but the mysterious sweet sauce made it good. The octopus was definitely my favorite dish. It wasn't very special, but something about it made it addicting. Their drinks are also pretty good. I had some special Nutella drink that the waitress recommended. The drink came in a fake Nutella jar and tastes nothing like Nutella, but  I guess it had a SLIGHT hazelnut flavor and it was very alcoholic... which I enjoyed. The waitress was really nice, and the staff was extremely professional. The bill was pretty high, but I would come here again if I ever come back to London!

Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

PoTWciB806JDFoN7x_FowQ.text: Heard of this place on a Best of London list, and decided to try it based on some of the strange items on the menu. We had the cornbread, pig ears, ox cheek doughnut, foie gras crême brulee, tuna, and of course the duck and waffle. Everything was very flavorful and unlike anything we'd ever had before! The duck and waffle was my favorite, the duck was well prepared and perfectly seasoned over a crisp, soft waffle. Topped with an egg and comes with syrup for you to add to your liking. A must try! Would definitely go back here to try other dishes. Make reservations well in advance!

F2E5ZOV1loBlHNrd06K94A.text: I came home late on Friday night and couldn't fall asleep and opened the Yelp App. As it was 3am, it recommended that I go eat at Duck & Waffle if I'm hungry. Seeing that it was opened so late and has a 4 star review, I curiously opened up the business page to see what this place was about, and found through the Yelp reviews that:1. It has a gorgeous view of london on the 40th floor2. It has a really interesting menu (pig ears, oxtail donut, duck confit with waffles)3. It opens 24-7 4. Reservation is recommended but I can do it directly via open table on YelpI decided then that I would make a reservation and clicked on Open Table only to find that regardless of which dates i provide, I can't get a reservation!!!! At this point, it's 4am and I have become a bit delirious. I need to find out how a restaurant can be completely booked for the rest of life if it's opened 24-7. Is it that good???I got up from my bed and turned on my computer instead. I opened the Open Table website in an attempt to figure out what the next available date is, and it's THREE MONTHS from now. Three dinner slots are available, none the days before and none the days after. How is this even possible, they're open 24 hours, seven days a week!I then began to research their walk-in policies, but i couldn't find it anywhere. At 5am, I decided I would call them. After two consecutive calls, no one answered. I started to give in, and decided I really should go to bed and stop the derelict obsession. I sent an email to their reservations asking about their policies on walk in and then went to bed.I woke up the next morning and saw their reply asking me to call them. It turned out that open table only takes dinner reservations between specific hours, which is why it's so difficult to book. ***If you call them or email them directly, they can slot you in as long as they have availabilities. They don't recommend that you walk in for eating (you can for their bar) but will take your reservation for any time. They want you to make a reservation even for 1am, though you likely won't *need* one. They won't let you walk up if they are really fully booked so it's better if you just call ahead.I ended up making a breakfast reservation for the next morning at 8am. We arrived early, at 7:30am and the restaurant was near empty. We were seated by the window at the East corner so we can watch the sunrise. The restaurant didn't fill up until almost 10am for their brunch menu.Unfortunately, their breakfast menu was very small - with maybe 4 or 5 main items. I got the duck and waffle (£15) and my bf got the banana brulee (£9). Coffee is £4 and comes with warm milk (nice touch), and freshly squeezed orange juice is £5.5. Expensive drinks.I liked the waffle, but was not that impressed with the duck confit (I live in paris after all) as it was a little too dry. The banana brulee was amazing, as it had hard caramel on top of the split in half banana. Chocolate syrup, vanilla ice cream, and waffles. YUM!  After a duck and waffle, banana brulee and waffle, a side breakfast sausage that look like intestines, three coffees and two orange juice, the damage was about £65. Overall I wasn't too impressed with the food but maybe dinner might be better. Service was fantastic and the but the ambiance is unparalleled. The view was the best part. So worth it. Next time I'm in the city, I'm totally booking for sunset!

G746XMX6OU9GfPJBltZUkA.text: Great food.  Duck waffle , fries and vegetable dishes are all good.  Brussel sprouts are way too oily.  It's more like deep fried than roasted.

K029XoIA_nlZ7WHi8ArD8Q.text: So So So.... My amazing boyfriend brought me here for a pre-valentines brunch. The view is what made this place for me! I am a sucker for views and this place delivered.We both had the infamous Duck and waffle which was yummy!! Crispy soft duck,fluffy waffle and a fried egg for good measure !! I was so distracted by the view I lost my concentration on the food lol .. Looks like I'll have to go back !!  We had their mimosas which weren't as champagne-yyyy as I usually have mine but that's life haha.. Service was fine and they were polite. The boy did good ..he did good

ycZcaMQxbTpsgKA_sDOpjg.text: The main attraction of this place is the spectacular view from the 40th floor. This means you need to try to make a reservation way in advance for the window seat. For starters, we ordered gruyere and nduja on bread and beef tartare. Both starters came in a generous portion and tasted delicious. For mains, we ordered none other than the famous duck and waffle. I would say the duck was very well cooked. The meat was tender and juicy, it was not too salty yet was well marinated. I'm knocking off a star as the waffle was way too normal. I think Waffle Meister on Bond Street does better waffle than Duck & Waffle.

p9-O0B0y5akwbme4V4Xnjg.text: As usual Duck & Waffle was perfect: great service, excellent food and astonishing view over London. I had a very brunch to celebrate my birthday, we had the egg cocotte and the signature dish the duck & waffle with a glass of Champagne.We shared a dessert, the dark chocolate brownie sundae, it was nice however the brownie was a bit too hard in our opinion (we both prefer soft brownie).

WQmlSXRIijjog28cMJ9xfw.text: The view: fabulousThe restaurant: way cooler than I am.  Beautiful plates, beautiful servers, cool bar.The food: creative, delicious, beautiful.We recommend everything we ordered:Smoked elk, homemade butter bread, miso-glazed rabbit, oxtail donut, puy lentils with sweet onions and nasturtiums, pork ears, and the roasted chicken.Get the roasted chicken.  I think I died eating it.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Get all these things and more.

jhUcPgb1Ma-Iyr8Cu3s4GA.text: Duck and Waffle was at the top of restaurants that we wanted to go to on our London visit.  We showed up on a monday for breakfast without a reservation (big mistake by the way), and luckily they were able to accommodate us.  It was an avery easy decision for me when it came to ordering, what else would one get here, the duck and waffle, obvi.  Not only is the view of the city amazing from the 40th floor, but depending where you sit in the dining room, you can see your food being prepared in front of you.  The duck and waffle does come to about $30 CAD, but it was totally worth it.  The waffle was crisp, and the skin and meat on the duck was delicious.  One tip, enjoy the 40 sec elevator ride to the top of the building, it's the best view of the city.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Duck and Waffle
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. The Gherkin

moeIzGNUbxw0Ml4mkP0cuA.text: Now now, I know there's a Long waiting list to get a table at this place, and that most come for the view rather than the food, and that also most will have the dish the place is named after - duck and waffle. Nothing wrong with the dish, the duck is confit to perfection, and the waffle with mustard maple syrup compliments it nicely, but there are so many other hidden gems about the place. It must have been my lucky day that I managed to get a booking for the next day, and at the 11.45am slot. But luckier still to be able to try out a starter plate that captured my imagination, and remains on my mind to this day, almost a full fortnight later. I'm talking about none other than the foie gras Creme brûlée with slowly warmed brioche and pork crackling drizzled on TOP. I mean, what's more to describe, the name of the dish is enough to get your saliva glands going into overdrive. Seriously, what more can I say? It is as good as it sounds. So, by all means, go to Duck and Waffle. But don't forget the little starter plate that once you have, will obsess your mind for a Long time.

Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

msHUtxp-HbTuaaeqtLM0DA.text: Amazing!!  Duck confit over waffle with sunny side up duck egg; great cappuccino - and a 40-story high unparalleled view of London....this place is a MUST!!

3rEgriycPL2pgLNnuOBGYQ.text: We went there on a Thursday night. We were lucky to sit on a table next to the view! The ambiance was pleasant. We ordered 2 desserts: Nutella waffles and white chocolate cake. Personally I did not like the cake it was not juicy enough. I would recommend the place because of it is nice atmosphere and its view!

cNbJ4pMHJLrK_ztXc8lNMQ.text: It was a huge disappointment because I heard so much great review about their duck & waffle. The truth is that the dish is okay, but I mean for all the troubles that I took to make the reservation and dine at 6pm... it is mediocre.... other foods were also average, so were the drinks they offered...

quVTWqcgCcqi5vQiaMG6WA.text: Duck & Waffle isn't just a restaurant, it's an experience. And it's an experience I wish I could have everyday for the rest of my life. But alas, one can only dream.My friends and I had a late dinner reservation on Wednesday evening, mainly because we had just flown in from San Francisco and booked something the day of. We take the elevators up the 40th floor, which was super thrilling in itself. There is a free coat check, a panoramic view of the city, cheeky bartenders, and expensive decor that is just dripping #CHIC. Couple things that stood out-+service: from the host, to the bartender, to the server- everyone was in good spirits, accommodating, and made our experience pleasant. Our party didn't arrive all together at once because a few were working late hours, but no worries we were seated right away and chatted over apps and drinks while waiting for the rest of the crew to arrive. Despite being one of the most upscale restaurants in London, not a drop of pretentiousness or snootiness was felt here. +bbq spiced pig ears: doesn't sound too appetizing, but was unique and had a nice crunch. Sort of addicting to be honest, couldn't stop snacking on it after it arrived in a brown bag. +duck & waffle: duh. who would come without trying the signature dish. Leg confit was crispy yet tender, and the duck egg on top really brought it over the edge. The sweetness of the maple syrup and saltiness of the duck & egg complemented each other fantastically on a neutral backdrop of the fluffy waffle. +whole sea bass: don't ask questions, just order it. Sea bass was rich & buttery, and the presentation was regal.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. the view & decor is unreal

v4vMiQmlIVHTVkV_BqCZzw.text: Loved to duck and waffle entree. Sweet and salty with a kick. Even the pig's ears were tasty. Great pinos grigio wine selection. Excellent service. Spectacular view of London from the 32 floor. HINT. Make reservations in advance. We couldn't get a reservation until 2:45 PM, but it was well worth it.

HbOM0LkN8lzCpib9901MWg.text: This is easily one of the coolest restaurants I have ever been to. First off, the elevator just to get to the restaurant is unreal. It blasts you up 40 floors at hyper-speed with rainbow lights and an all glass enclosure for great views. Next, right when you walk in is a bar in the middle of a room with bartenders making drinks right in front of you. There are neat lights hanging everywhere, graffiti walls, dim lighting - very cool vibes. Keep in mind, this is all before you even get to the hostess table. The dining room was just as cool. There is an open kitchen so you can watch everything being made. The windows were a little fogged at the time, but I know there was a great view on the other side. The wine list was pretty extensive and there were a number of great cocktails to choose from. To start, we had to go with the duck & waffle, which the restaurant is obviously named after. What a dish! It's got an egg on top and is plated in such a cool way. Highly recommend as your starter to share with the table. Then we got two of the bigger shareable dishes (for 4 total), one fish and one beef. They were both incredible. The meat was cooked perfectly to my liking. The fish wasn't dry at all. Both came over some nice sauce with vegetables. Our server Michael from Poland was hilarious. He was very helpful making recommendations and even cut our duck for us ha. We never knew whether or not to tip in London (coming from America) but we absolutely had to for Michael. Make sure you make reservations ahead of time so you can experience this wonderful place! They are somehow open 24/7, so you'll be able to find something available if you're willing to eat later in the evening. Although it's a little out of the way towards Shoreditch, this is a must in London, especially if you're a foodie!

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

6oWaus97FY8pK95JmJjw-g.text: Possibly the top meal of the trip to London. Came by here a bit later in the night 1am (they're open 24/7), and there was still a tad bit of a wait, but after waiting about 15 minutes we were let in, and shot up to the 40th floor. I typically never say anything about views, but this has gotta be one of the best places to see London from the sky.Getting back on track we ordered a few things:The Duck and Waffle: The Staple here. The waffle was super crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. The Duck was juicy and delicious. Just keep in mind here that if you're here with 3 people you'll probably want to order 2 of these. Get This. The BBQ Pig Ears: The surprise of the night. The waiter came by and dropped off a bag with a wax stamp that sealed it, and inside were hot crispy bbq seasoning dusted pig ears. These things were Fire! Get this. Smoked Salmon w Avo Toast and Scrambled Eggs: Everything on this was ok. Nothing special here though. Skip This. In the end we were pretty shocked that the bill was less than 60GBP. That view up there is everything though, and the duck and those pig ears were memorable. Definitely check this place out if you're in London. FYI: Fri and Sat (not late night) they dont allow athleisure wear, so dress the part if you plan to go then. Also, they prepared the duck and waffle differently than the more casual location in picadilly, so if you havent been to this one specifically I'd say try this one out as it was better in my book.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. That view tho!

J6ToakalDBmtu-rxTbnmAg.text: Cons:-Food was alright. Waffle was soggy. -One star off due to the bad service: Had to call server twice to add more water. Servers seem like they don't like their job at all. Pros:Good views

P9THzuUZMA9NoreicJE2Ig.text: As one of the hottest and hyped up places in London, our food adventure in the city wouldn't have been complete without a visit to the famous Duck & Waffle!We made a reservation over a month in advance and the earliest table available was 9:30pm on a Wednesday night! With reservations so difficult to procure, eating here feels almost exclusive, and they don't quite let you forget it - you still need to confirm your reservation 24-72 hours beforehand, there's a £20 charge per person if you no-show or cancel less than 24 hours in advance, and there's a smart casual dress code so dress to impress!Dining here is definitely an experience from start to finish, and with no lack of spectacular views. Beginning with the glass elevator ride up to the 40th floor speeding up over the city below, you then enter the hip and trendy bar area where you can enjoy some creative cocktails as you wait to be seated. There's even a lit-up set of stairs leading down to Sushi Samba on the floor below which provides yet another photo opportunity and place to gawk over the views. We were fortunate to be seated at a fantastic corner table tucked next to the window, allowing the sprawling city lights to be the backdrop for our dinner!One of the impressive things about Duck & Waffle is that they are open 24/7; they have different menus for various times of day, but one thing that is consistent for all of them is their specialty and namesake - the duck and waffle - which, of course, we had to order. I was intrigued by and knew I wanted to get the spiced duck doughnut and foie gras creme brûlée to try as well.The duck and waffle, consisting of duck confit over a waffle topped with a fried duck egg and syrup, was pretty good, but perhaps a bit overrated, and a tad smaller than expected. What really stole the show for me was the SPICED DUCK DOUGHNUT! Words cannot describe the deliciousness of this huge ball of flavor...served on a bed of pineapple jam, covered in paprika sugar, and with tasty duck inside the layers of soft dough, I probably could've ordered another one (or two) to just enjoy by myself. Finally, the foie gras creme brûlée was interesting, yet another well done mix of sweet and savory and paired well with the pork crackling and marmalade brioche it came with. Service was not as pretentious as expected, which was a pleasant surprise! Our drink and food orders were taken and delivered fairly quickly, and our server was friendly and efficient. There was a lot of shuffling of us around from the stairs to the bar to our seats but the employees we did interact with were generally helpful.This was not a cheap dinner by any means, with the cocktails at £14 each, duck and waffle at £18, doughnut at £12, etc. The dining room was also packed extremely full and was bustling and loud, so probably not a great place if you're trying to relax with some quiet conversation. However, if you're looking for some good food (at any hour of day!), a vibrant, very alive late night atmosphere, and/or just a cool overall experience, it's worth a visit at least once while in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Foie gras creme brulee with pork crackling and marmalade brioche
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Duck and waffle, spiced duck doughnut
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Duck and waffle

wRwdVwlBO5bNxVD-vDDLDg.text: Wonderful bar experience at the Duck and Waffle. Dismayed I didn't have the foresight to book a table, but had a lovely time nonetheless. If you make your way there, make sure to check out the view from the grand spiral staircase while sipping on a Pink Peppercorn Lemonade or a Ristretto Negroni. The peppercorn flavor was wonderfully balanced in that cocktail, and the Negroni touts a 24 hr slow dropped coffee. Both are delicious...and don't forget to get a munchie -- I recommend the crispy bbq pig ears. Prices are a bit steep, and it is quite hard to get in a reservation for a table, so plan ahead. Wonderful service from Alexander. Hope to come back and try the main courses and bump up to a 5 Star.

lSae6S_ct0wtnG_MHB9i0w.text: This has to be one of the most difficult reservations to make in the World. Online reservations open up 2 months in advance and popular times are snatched up very quickly.  They also require a credit card guarantee - no shows or cancellations in less than 24 hours will result in a fee of GBP20 per person. The last few times we were in London, I didn't book far ahead enough and never got a chance to go there.  This time, I made our reservation about 6 weeks in advance and the "best available" time for a Friday night was 9:30PM.  I grabbed that right away and happily entered my credit card information to guarantee the spot.Upon arrival we skipped the long line outside the building (which was for people going to the bar or had no reservations and hoping to get in if there were enough no shows) and went straight to the receptionist.  He verified our reservation and let us in the door to go through security.  After that we rode the private glass elevator to the 40th floor (if you are afraid of heights just don't look outside).When we reached the dining room, the hostess verified our reservation and led us to a window table which I had requested.  Once we sat down, we saw the World famous Gherkin building almost right in front of our eyes.  Looking further down, we saw the River Thames and the beautifully lit-up Tower Bridge.So what would you order at Duck and Waffle?  Duck and waffle, I guess?Absolutely!  And that must be the best duck confit that I've ever had.  The skin was perfectly paper-thin, golden brown and crispy, and had completely separated from the meat.  The duck was so tender, moist, and flavorful that it tasted almost heavenly.  The amateur gourmet chef in me would guess that it had been marinated overnight and then slowed cooked in its own natural juices and fat for hours.The portion size of the waffle was rather small but delicious and went well with the duck.  If you've ever had chicken and waffle and like the combination, you'll fall in love with this dish.  The final touch of the dish was the sunny side up duck egg.  So how's a duck egg different from a regular (chicken) egg?  I would say not much difference in the egg white, but the duck egg's yoke is a lot thicker and richer.We also shared an order of spinach and ricotta ravioli, which was served with a watercress puree in pea broth, and garnished with roasted almonds.  The dish was delicious but outshined by the duck and waffle.We decided to bypass dessert but took the opportunity to sample a plate of European cheeses to finish our wine.  That turned out to be an excellent decision as those European cheeses were so amazing and provided the perfect finishing touches to a delightful and memorable dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Duck and waffle.
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Spinach and ricotta ravioli.
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. View from our table.

p7LynFytUvp_PTP_QT0_oA.text: We made brunch reservations 2 months in advance and landed a coveted window seat. Ordered the following dishes.duck and waffle - cute presentation. duck confit is extremely flavorful. Loved the crispy skin and duck is succulent. Green tea pairing was excellent! Duck congee - a bit of ginger. Unique dish.   Oxtail doughnut - breaks apart so easily. Airy on the inside with delicious spiced oxtal. Food came out extremely quickly. Can easily finish the brunch within an hour if you're short on time. I'd highly recommend visiting for a unique brunch experience.

bztUL50aqqdhyPWBs9zY0A.text: Arrived for brunch on a Sunday afternoon travelling solo for work. First the doorman at the foot of 110 Bishopsgate advised there weren't any tables and rightly advised there wasn't any food served in the bar. I was surprised to be able to make a reservation on their website for a 1-person table for 12.45, the exact time I was standing at their front door. The doorman was surprised to see me return and phoned up to the hostess who confirmed I had a booking - I'd had to entry my credit card number so they could charge me £20 in the case of a no show, so I was hoping they'd honour the reservation. The doorman seemed less interested in welcoming me and more in telling the hostess that he was turning people away and that he needed to be better informed, in spite of his tablet getting live bookings like mine. Upstairs the hostess welcomed me and took me through to the restaurant floor, only to realise that the table hadn't yet been reset. A short stint in the bar, where I was offered a menu but didn't get the chance to order anything, and I was back at table looking out at a strikingly grey Square Mile.The waiter struggled with me wanting a "black coffee", the choice of filter or a black americano muddied with offers of lattes and cappuccinos. My americano eventually arrives with a side of hot milk which I advise the waitress I won't be using. My sparkling water is topped up a passing floor manager in a tie, finally allowing me to order my House Breakfast. Its a £16 fry up and doesn't disappoint with a good amount of bacon, two beautifully poached eggs with bright orangey, yellow yikes. The chefs are on top of things, shame about everybody else. No one checks on me during my meal, my coffee runs out half way through my breakfast but we've given up topping up my water glass now so I don't get the chance to order a second from my waiter or anyone else. Having completed my breakfast I sit for too long waiting to have my plate clear. I ask my waiter for the bill, having been offered more drinks, but instead watch him busily take orders and interact with other customers. Apparently my cheque has gotten lost. Another floor manager approaches my table asking if everything is alright. I tell him I'm waiting for my bill and that the service has been lacking. He thanked me for my feedback and comped my coffee as well as removing the service fee. I wasn't the right customer for them. I wasn't spending big bucks on £14 brunch cocktails and chilling with friends for the two and a half hours the booking engine had alloted for my visit, but apparently their army of staff and 13.5% service fee are not enough to see the service match the price tag.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

VfI4_DSMNcd1FlGYz-lb4w.text: Really good food, for sure the best black pudding I ever had! They where a bit anal about their time schedule. "Be on time, don't be late, make sure you are here in good time, you have 45 mins at your table and that's it" sending emails and calling before we arrived, but once we were there they did not rush us, but I still had that inner clock ticking which made at least my experience a little less good. Without that I would have given them four stars.We were celebrating my daughters birthday and they congratulated her which I appreciate, we also had really nice champagne drinks and prompt service. The people watching and the view of London is 100% thumbs up here.

nz79Zlk5PaGzbfTxoau9rw.text: Duck and Waffle is a place you visit for the views, you pay a premium for the food and drinks to enjoy it. It's a bit hard to find at night (look for the express elevator next to Sushi Samba and a few taxis out front). I LOVED that they were open 24 hours (even the kitchen!) so when I was jet lagged I came up to enjoy the beautiful nighttime skyline and their famous foie gras creme brulee with toasted brioche.The creme brulee was really dense and rich. Served with brioche and jam that was a little too sweet. I enjoyed something nearly identical and much better at Sage in Las Vegas. 3 stars for food, 4.5 stars for views and ambiance!

JPP0YtWwK3ftaSuGaD6phw.text: I love Duck and Waffle - both for the view and the good. Order: Caramelized Banana Waffle; Duck and Waffle Waffle; latte; cappuccinoAvoid: arriving late as they only hold your table 15 mins and are normally very busy Situated in the business area of London, this restaurant is in an impressive skyscraper on the 40th story (if you are afraid of heights, this may not be the best place for you - try Duck and Waffle Local instead). To get to the restaurant, you check in at the bottom with a receptionist who will let you into the elevators. Take in the view as you quickly travel 40 stories. Once you reach the 40th floor, you walk past the bathrooms and through the bar to reach the main dining area. Try to get a seat on the window, no matter what direction you face, you will have beautiful views. You can even see the gherkin, Tower of London, and tower bridge! Also keep in mind, you only have 1 hour and 15 mins at your table on busy days, so READ THE MENU BEFOREHAND so you don't waste time looking at your menu instead of outside. I love the caramelized banana waffle. It is  1/2 a waffle served with 1 whole, brûléed banana on top of a tasty Nutella-like spread. This is all topped with a yummy vanilla ice cream. You can also ask for a plain waffle with maple syrup, but remember it's only  1/2 a waffle so you might get hungry later. If you enjoy savory waffles, I highly recommend their Duck and Waffle - it is truly delicious and incredibly flavorful. Strangely you cannot order their pastry basket, which comes with 1 croissant, 1 pain au chocolat, and 1 raisin pastry, with only the pastries you want. You must get these three pastries, which I found odd and unnecessary. As far as drinks go, they have good espresso drinks. Also, the Bloody Mary is quite spicy but has a very nice flavor - make sure to ask for salt on the rim. I would come here again - if not for the view then for food. It is always a bright, yummy place to bring people, especially those new to London. Make reservations well ahead of time - during the busier summer months and Christmas time, they get very packed very quickly. Do not arrive late and look at the menu beforehand to really enjoy the experience.

z-ds6BNPZEAFb4qiW-OURQ.text: They did not want to let a good friend of mine intoThe restaurant because he was wearing "ultra boost" Adidas shoes. He flew there for a business meeting, because he too owns several restaurants with his respectful Iron chef father, also partnered with rapper Drake. He knows restaurant business. And his establishments which are more reputable than this place do not turn people down because of their shoes. This is very disappointing and discriminating, I would not recommend this place at all. Horrible service.

HfkfrDVbVe8pAXs1fRb_UA.text: We came here to get sushi. What is this s**t!?! Burnt squash was not burnt at all, not even charred. They served it absolutely raw for $22! Service was terrible, the servers couldn't enunciate for their lives, and the hostess was oblivious and completely unhelpful!!! I was so hungry I was able to get a few bites down, but only while GAGGING and holding back vomit!!!!!! I need to stop typing now before I break my fucking phone out of frustration

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

6u24Ghs7-3oqm3tsnDbXaA.text: We arrived 30 minutes earlier than our reservation time. We were greeted in the small elevator area by a hostess who checked our reservation. We were then waived over to go up the elevators to the duck and waffle 40th floor. The ride up was great because the view was beautiful. I would rather eat at a place a view then paying for an attraction just to see the same view.we walked over to the bar area after exiting the elevator to go to the next hostess. She told us that we were a little early and to have a seat. We ordered a couple of drinks and we had an opportunity to take some pictures with the view. I really enjoyed the look of the bar area and the bartender seemed really experienced but there was only one person for a room that had a least 12 people. we were escorted to our table by our hostess and unfortunately didn't get the coveted window view. The entire restaurant had a pretty good view regardless of where you sat. Another unfortunate event was being seated very closely to the kitchen. The kitchen was hot and the restaurant was hot. This combined made our sitting location really uncomfortable. we were greeted by our waiter and he brought over water with ice in a separate bowl for us to put into our water. My boyfriend ordered the duck and waffle and I ordered the duck soufflé.  I wasn't really hungry due to the heat. We constantly could hear the head chef shouting orders to the kitchen staff. It seemed like she ran a really tight ship but the staff seemed to not skip a beat. The soufflé wasn't great. The crown of the soufflé was really tough and hard to break into. I had to work to get every bite. My boyfriends waffle was alright as well. It was nothing too amazing but he enjoyed the duck. The rave reviews and the fancy atmosphere of dress code and deposit money for your reservations made me believe this would be an amazing experience. I wasn't really impressed but the view was good.

JfSlzIK3oygvxauzMdinog.text: Whoever is doing the PR for Duck & Waffle deserves a raise-- this spot is listed in damn near every "Where to Eat in London" article on the internet, and really shouldn't belong there. After making our reservation over a month in advance, we finally roll up to the entrance at 8AM for our breakfast. After being shot up 40 floors in the elevator, we sit down at our table. It's a fairly easy menu, not having a ton of options, especially given the duck & waffle is the must-have. My partner and I ordered one Duck & Waffle and one Ox Cheek Benedict. We each enjoyed our respective meals, and disliked the others' ironically enough. The food itself was good, and the views really are spectacular, but I honestly don't believe that it merits such a high price point. The food was certainly good, but tiny little portions for the price. For 16 pounds, you can serve a whole waffle. The thing dragging down this rating though, was the haughty attitude of nearly every employee we interacted with. The hostess, server, security, and manager all spoke to us condescendingly and smugly, as if it were a gift they were allowing us to be in their restaurant. We made sure to dress up, as we noted the dress code and are very polite, kind people. We had no idea why we were talked down to. It rubbed us entirely the wrong way, and I do not plan on returning.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

_1TlmO41z8D8-t2dXaOHkQ.text: I'd give this review 4 stars for the food but the service is bumping it down one star. We had a reservation for 11:45pm on a Tuesday night, but there were plenty of open tables on arrival so I suspect a reservation wouldn't have been necessary. We ordered crispy pig ears, the duck & waffle, and duck egg en cocotte. And also ordered the Green Gimlet and Piña Kale-ada.1) The pig ears were a HIT. The texture put a fun twist on a typical french fry and the BBQ seasoning was very flavorful. I wish we hadn't eaten them so quickly.2) The duck & waffle came with a sunny side up egg. The waffle and egg were nothing spectacular but the duck was great. Not dry, crispy outside and tender inside and went well with the maple syrup. £18 its a bit steep for the dish but I guess the cost is taking into account the ambience and view of London 3) Duck egg en cocotte was NOT what I was expecting in the most pleasant way possible. A fried duck egg sat in a small cast iron skillet drowned in gruyere and truffles. Small breadsticks were on the side for dipping. This was my favorite dish.4) The Green Gimlet was alright, pretty clean and nice if you like gin. Fair warning, if you want a green drink, this is not green. It's clear as water.5) Now if you want a green drink, the piña kale-ada is pretty fucking green. Topped with toasted kale and a dried pineapple slice, the drink itself was sweet and not bitter. I got the non-alcoholic version for £7 but it does come with rum for £14 The food was good but overpriced, understandably so.But the service was all over the place. We had 6 different waitors serving our table and we had to ask different servors multiple times for refills/napkins etc because none of them seemed to be assigned our table. The man who took our order was extremely rude and arrogant, who didn't seem to understand what customer service is. When he came to our table, he slouched against the wall and bluntly asked "What do you want?" Later, when we asked to see the full cocktail menu, he basically told us "There's no point, it's not going to tell you anything but fine I'll get it." He definitely made a bad impression on the restaurant but the other 5 waitors were nothing like him.Overall impression: expensive over-hyped duck recipes with a nice view of the city and club-like ambience. This place is more for the aesthetic than for the food experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. The Classic Duck & Waffle (only comes with half a waffle)
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Duck Egg en Cocotte
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Green Gimlet (left) and Pina Kale-ada (right)

PWDrgWO0ilFQmnQ1nocoMg.text: Wow, well worth the price.Yes! Dress code is important! They seem like they'll try not to be rude about your clothing by pointing it out, but definitely in the evening people are wearing nicer dresses, nicer shoes (some heels), and button up. I don't recommend wearing sneakers, Converse, flip flops, shorts, lighter denim shades or T-shirts. The 40 flight ascent was so beautiful to capture. Though we had reservations, we had to wait about 15 minutes in the bar area before we could sit. The restaurant area is small, but it was good for being able to see the view no matter where you sat. We didn't get a window seat, but we still could gaze out at the view around us. Service was alright. I'd say everyone was nice, but it was confusing at times. We had a total of 4 people help us and weren't even sure who to ask for certain things. The man who welcomed us gave a nice guide to the menu. Then another took our order and ended up forgetting the drinks, then bringing back one wrong order. Then we didn't see him the rest of the night so maybe he ended his shift?All that aside, I thought the food was stellar.I had a bacon wrapped date (3.5 pounds) which was tiny, but really packed with flavor. Theres a mix of cheese and meat filling the date, and it's all wrapped with salty bacon. The date flavor isn't very strong since it's so heavy on meat, and the mustard sauce made it overall a savory snack. It was definitely a fun bite.The maple jalapeno cornbread came out steaming hot! It was delicious, but just tasted like your standard cornbread with a bit more heat.The DUCK DOUGHNUT (12 pounds), is a big WOW. Highly recommend! It's not like a pate filling, but a sort of ground up meat inside. But I was mostly fascinated by the bread itself: it's not like normal-donut fluffy, but it's a more dense version that still can qualify as fluffy. The spiced outside made this crunchy outer to this soft bite, and I couldn't get enough.The duck and waffle looked so small on Yelp, but the duck confit was actually near the size of a 1/4 chicken leg! The waffle was half the size it should be, and the egg was standard. Holy, the meat was really good. I think duck is one of my new favorite meats to have. It's like chicken, but fattier, and therefore more flavorful. You have to have a full bite that fits part of the egg, duck, waffle, and syrup into your mouth! It's a blessing.It was a splurge, but the experience was wonderful.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

EuwDBHAHLB3_rP4S3mqJDA.text: Beautiful restaurant and bar atop the 40th floor.   For a restaurant that opens 24/7, it was extremely hard to get a decent reservation time, but we managed to get a 10.30pm booking.   We got there early for drinks, but didn't realised they had a strict dress code.   Being a visitor in London, I was wearing my comfy sweat pants and tennis shoes, so that was a no no.   I had to go back to change pants in order to gain entry.  I ordered the signature duck and Waffle.   The duck was piping hot & very delicious, but the waffle was a little bit on the cold stale side.  Overall the meal was pretty good, but not good enough to go home to change pants for..... and at such a late hour for dinner..... not worth the wait.... somewhat overrated.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Duck and waffle
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Bread for the table
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Very cool waiting lounge

39NbfaC58FTSmGsTJG6Osw.text: So, I'd heard it was the hardest reservation to get in London and the menu looked intriguing. After lucking out with a dinner reservation at 8 o'clock I was able to cancel my 0645 breakfast plans there.  This was a really fun experience, there's lots of staff to take care of you, and the place is loaded with personality.  If I go back again before leaving town I'll request a booth because once I'd been there a while the wooden seat felt a bit hard after 10+ hours of flying.Anyway, the bar fixed one of their signature drinks made with whiskey and black cherry. We ordered a mass of stuff to try and were so full by the end that we couldn't eat much of the "entree" items. Anyway, feeling adventurous, I tried the pig ears--think BBQ potato chips (US) or crisps (UK)--which was a first in this lifetime and they were brilliant. Also brilliant was the lamb-stuffed lavash or Pita bread which was perfectly seasoned and awonderful flavor bomb. I also quite liked the ox cheek, duck and waffle and bacon-wrapped dates in a mustard sauce. Not such a huge fan of the foie gras Creme Brûlée or the Rabbit w/ Miso glaze.Overall, a great experience and I highly recommend a visit here because it just exudes so much personality and energy!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. The other of my two favorite items ... BBQ crispy pig ears, absolutely brilliant!
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Bacon wrapped dates with a pungent, delightfully spicy mustard sauce, liked it.
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

ogPM_CRS0lbaNUHWcD8cSg.text: One of the best meals I've ever had! Not only was the view spectacular, but the food was divine. I ordered their signature dish - the duck and waffle. Initially I was hesitant to try a meat with a waffle accompanied with maple syrup - however it was an amazing combination! It was also easy to find. Would definitely go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. View from window of restaurant.
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. View when entering restaurant

EFJFwuEGnw_7mX8avO7GUQ.text: Amazing view ,great food,top location.you want to be different -go to D&W..prices :50 P up..;)

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom

7eddXjUh5b5op5kVp800ew.text: Nava kept asking me if I wanted to go, and I managed to find a brunch booking at a very late 3:00 pm on a Sunday. So Nava, the other half, and I went to Duck and Waffle to give it a whirl.First off, it's quite difficult to find. There's a door that's not easy to find, and then you go in and take a lift to the 40th floor, where you go behind an unlabelled door, down a twisty corridor, and you finally find yourself at the restaurant. So the views are spectacular. It was not the sunniest of days, but the views were still fantastic. We opted to get a bunch of stuff to share. We had the Foie Gras all day breakfast, the crispy pig ears, the ox cheek doughnut, the bacon wrapped dates, and two orders of the duck and waffle (I mean, you ARE there, you should enjoy it right?) We also had a round of bloody marys and a bottle of champagne while we were eating.The food is fantastic. The best was the dates. Nicely sweet and salty and delicious. You can never go wrong with foie gras seared on brioche, a quail egg, some black pudding, and a sweet nutty syrup. The ox cheek doughnut was also great and original. I've never had a doughnut stuff with meat, but I'll definitely have something like it again. The pig ears were sliced thin and deep fried. Very very well done. The duck and waffle was also pretty fantastic. The mustard maple syrup on top of the waffles, duck egg and duck confit gave it something special.Most of the dishes do the combination of sweet and savoury well. Which for brunch is perfect. We opted for dessert. We had the brownie with peanut butter ice cream and the Christmas pudding. The pudding was good, but nothing great, but the brownie dessert was pretty spectacular (especially if you like peanut butter). We also had a bottle of Maury to go with it, so it made it even more special.By the time we left, it had gotten dark (thanks to going so late in the day during the winter), so we also got to see the view with the city of London lit up below us. I'm definitely looking forward to going back and trying even more of the crazy dishes on the menu!

vBhCjXgzfzM_9RzntFNafg.text: Top banana this place.An unrivalled view over the greatest city in the world and some proper Sunday brunch tucker to go with it. Big comfy booth to enjoy it all from and relaxed, unhurried but totally efficient service with a smile.I could have eaten everything on the menu. In fact I tried. Oysters to start. Plump and fresh as a daisy. Followed by some crispy pigs ears to start. Yes that's a second starter. 'All for me when your partner's pork free'. Served in a cute little paper bag so you eat them like crisps. Oh and some bread and olives. But that doesn't count. Followed by a baked egg and truffle beauty that was richer than anything down below in the square mile.Stanley couldn't finish his waffles with ice cream and we couldn't finish it for him. That's a first, literally. We were thinking of the poor lift that needed to take us back down from what is officially the highest restaurant in Britain. Debs had the signature Duck and Waffle. Beautifully crisp confit with a perfect fried egg on a tasty waffle drizzled with sweet sauce with a hint of five spice. It's not rocket science, but who wants to eat rockets for Sunday Brunch? Perfect.A busy open kitchen is there to gaze into if you've had enough of the stunning views. And lots of excited tourists and homies taking pictures that will never ever do the vista justice. I defy anyone to be too cool and nonchalant not to get a shot themselves. It's OK, you're allowed to be blown away. That's the point.The whole afternoon was enormous fun. Indulgent, relaxing. I just wrote a review of the Tom's kitchen Sunday brunch experience and they couldn't be more different. We reluctantly heaved ourselves off after a quick tour around all four sides and a special look westwards to Shepherd's Bush to spot the floodlights at the home of football. The lift went back down super fast due to the extra weight, and when we got to the bottom we went up and down again. All the fun of the fair without the puke.A short walk to the madness of Spitalfields and Brick Lane to roughen the edges a little of a snazzy Sunday afternoon. A great place whether you're just visiting or a Londoner born and bred. You can only book two months ahead for the Sunday gig and it goes early so have your wits about you if you're on a schedule. Bring a camera and don't eat anything on Saturday.

aVBuEpdRTtyXIwqsGQKXSA.text: If you're coming here, make sure to call ahead of time for  guaranteed reservations. Even if they are opened 24/7, it's a pretty fancy place so walking in and dining lavishly right away with your friends will make the experience a lot more splendid. If you didn't make reservations and you find yourself needing to wait, the bar prior to entering the restaurant is open without wait time. The bar area is also the fanciest place for photos in my opinion! Good view and decorations hanging all around.So what to order? Obviously the Duck & Waffle, right? The waiter told my party that the dishes are sharing size and that we should only order 4 Duck & Waffles for my group of 8. Go home, waiter! You're drunk!! If you're coming to Duck & Waffle, you better order one for yourself and eat it all! The dishes aren't that big so definitely not "family style" as the waiter was trying to suggest. Also, if you're ordering small plates, skip the spicy ox cheek doughnut. As intriguing as it may look, it was neither spicy or tasty. Pretty tasteless piece of dough, no flavour unless you dipped it in the tiny apricot jam that comes with it. The caramelized onion bread with anchovy / caper or the roasted octopus, is a much better small plate choice!

ndQhCJjeg_4oF_LL9CWb_Q.text: Maybe because it was late, maybe because we didn't have a booking it maybe it was the woman straddling her date next to us but I wasn't really felling it. Will give it another go but definitely only with a booking.

5_2DmHNdmif_gVVKGIFOJA.text: Wow, can I move in here? My experience at Duck & Waffle was spectacular in every way. Even if the food was awful (which it wasn't), the service and ambiance alone would get me to come back. The restaurant is on the 40th floor of the Heron building and has sweeping views of the city all around - pretty much every table has great views all around. The décor is trendy yet laid back.The service was superb. I found our server to be extremely helpful as well as enthusiastic about the menu - she gave great recommendations. I had to opt for the duck & waffle plate, which was both the best duck and the best waffle I've had. It's topped with a duck egg and served with mustard maple syrup. The flavors came together in the most amazing way - I was legitimately depressed when I took my last bite. Our table was also lucky enough to snag the last available dossant order, and it was unlike any dessert I've had - the texture was truly amazing. I'm pretty sure you can't go wrong ordering here. Every plate of food that came out looked incredible.All in all, please go here. I am doing my best to become a regular.

tyGxd3STDoG4OOi44lff_g.text: - located on the 40th floor of Heron Tower in the City of London- we went there because of the nice view and we could not see anything because the windows were full of damp- reservation required (sometimes even weeks before)- friendly staff- a big variety of brunch specialities- you should try duck & waffle: crispy leg confit / fried duck egg / mustard maple syrup (15.00)- greek yoghurt with fruit and granola is very delicious (4.50; not sweet)- 3 egg omelette (pancetta / wild mushroom / cheddar) was too oily (8.00)- black tea with milk: 4.00- freshly squeezed orange juice: 3.00Since we went there for the view and the windows were full of damp and the food was good however not premium I will not award more than 3 stars.

9D836H8i84lLXGlSp5gBeQ.text: Get the duck and waffle!! It's the perfect combination of crispy duck, half a belgian waffle, duck egg, and maple syrup on top! If you don't like the idea of pouring maple syrup on top of everything, don't worry, as you get the syrup on the side. The foie gras creme brulee with lobster sounded rather intriguing, so we ordered that, as well as a wild mushroom and goat's cheese bread. The foie gras was a bit too sweet, but the texture was great. Lobster was also good. The bread was very tasty and was quite big (like a small pizza). Apart from the food, the restaurant has a great view and a nice atmosphere. I would definitely go again!

photos.caption: Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Duck and waffle
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Foie gras creme brulee with lobster
Photo of Duck & Waffle - London, United Kingdom. Wild mushroom and goat's cheese bread

JgwyaRcAAopOqiqEQhMUsw.text: What a location, this restaurant is located 40 floors above the streets of london in Heron Tower, the views are great. There is a nice waiting area at the top to have a drink and look at the views, take a look at the bottle lights, very modern. The seating area is great, nice table arrangement with sufficient space between tables. I had a range of starters including olives, bread and pigs ears, everything was fantastic. For my main I had the signature dish, the Duck and Waffle, oh boy I cannot describe how nice it was, it is a waffle with a crispy duck leg, fried egg on top with a side of maple syrup with mustard seeds. Granted it doesn't doing like you should put this together, but trust me, it is brilliant. If there were a 6th star I would click it. I will be going back in the near future.

9O5ulHwWm8tCzLMp-SxJtQ.text: Very interesting place. The staff feel a little mechanical because of the forceful processes in place. Slightly devoid of personality, but still very pleasant. We ordered an expensive bottle of wine on the advice of the sommelier and we weren't disappointed. I can honestly say it was the best wine I've ever tasted. We also had a glass of dessert wine that was much cheaper but still very good. The food was great, very interesting combinations which I must admit sometimes lost me. Such as egg and maple syrup, not for me! I didn't like how much foie gras on the menu either. But otherwise a superb experience. And did you know they're open 24 hours a day!

CBWu52eTUKA0luSslevnYw.text: I came here for the famous Duck & Waffle dish of course. Before going I was familiar with chicken & waffle, a guilty pleasure back in California enjoyed in casual (and rather greasy) dining contexts. With this experience in mind, I was taken aback by the trendy vibe and impressive atmosphere of the restaurant.The duck & waffle plate exceeded my expectations and honestly put Cali's chicken & waffle to shame (but I will always remember it as my introduction to this unusual type of pairing). What really sold me on the restaurant was its location, 40 floors up in central London. The view of the city is unlike any other I've seen and is truly magical at night. The decor adds to this ambiance with an edgy flavor that simultaneously manages to maintain classy simplicity.Unfortunately the bar tender was out the night I went, but I will definitely be making a trip back to try their cocktails as their descriptions were all too tempting. What could be better than a delicious cocktail overlooking the city of London? Oh ya, some duck & waffle to follow it up!

k7e9L6438agXmqV2f8vL9g.text: An incredible view, an energetic vibe, courteous and efficient service, and good food. Well worth the effort to get a reservation. Be sure to check out the extensive gin list and don't be shy in asking for direction from the knowledgeable bartenders.

lY-gKRxYvPNUAzWY3kgZ_g.text: Took my dad for his birthday. My dads not used to super fancy places and cab often feel intimidated. But the atmosphere in there is so welcoming we didn't feel out of place at all. The lift up us the best bit!

CSSFwJpobZkYrezSUyxciQ.text: Been here a couple of times and it's always amazing! Book in advance as tables are hard to get!

uWXWjYfJ5p9C5QDeskr6yA.text: My husband went to London for business, I got to tag along. We were basically stuck on Chicago time the entire time and could not sleep. We didn't want to order room service the second night we were there, so we did an online search to see if there were any restaurants open 24 hours. I was expecting a place called Duck & Waffle to be a small diner of some sorts, boy was I wrong!The decor is modern, upscale, whimsical and unique. It was half empty, as expected at 4am. A handful of people were there clearly to wind down from partying the night before. A few people like us probably couldn't sleep and were there for breakfast as well. Point being, we didn't know what a popular spot this was and glad we were able to beat the crowd.The restaurant is 40 floors in the sky with gigantic windows, wow what an unexpected treat that was! We got to see the sun rise overlooking the beautiful city of London. Couldn't ask for a better view to accompany our breakfast! The food was amazing as well. We started off with a cappuccino and latte, both very good. I got the Berries 'n' Cream Belgian Waffle...honestly the best breakfast I have had in a long time. So simple, but executed perfectly. I seriously considered ordering another order of belgian waffles just to try the nutella/banana combination. That will have to wait until our next trip to London though, I was already full. My husband got the famous Duck 'n' Waffle and an extra side of eggs with sourdough toast. He is typically hard to please but was very happy with this food. Definitely recommend this place as a must visit if ever in the city of London!

lfqERGVwIFkCiR2gMWTuZg.text: My date insisted on taking me here - what a star he is. We scored the prime view table as soon as we came in. Utterly romantic, excellent service, and all was delicious. Negronis, oysters and tartar - the perfect pre-dinner snack. I think we could see Heathrow (just kidding - but maybe?). You really can see for miles. Even the elevator ride does't disappoint.

xwPPAFnGUTiiAXBm_NgN_A.text: The grilled cheese sandwich with ox cheek was phenomenal and will return for that alone. Oh, and they view is epic even for a city not known for skyscrapers.

9bU2RIWlENLh07E1LWlJjQ.text: There are two dishes that Duck & Waffle are known for: the eponymous 'duck and waffle' and the ox cheek doughnut with apricot jam.  My wife ordered the duck and waffle and I had the ox cheek doughtnut for a lunch dessert.The duck and waffle was excellent: you must get a forkful of confit duck, waffle and maple syrup together to get the full taste experience.  The doughnut was a bit too doughy for my liking, but I liked the tender ox cheek filling. The sweetness of the apricot jam went quite well with the savouriness of the other components.We ordered a few other things, aside from the headline dishes.  We got some pig ear crackling (which came in a bag with some cajun coating).  This was moreish and I was regularly licking the tasty coating off from my fingers.  I had the duck egg cocotte, with gruyere cheese, mushrooms and truffle oil. This was also tasty, but unfortunately there wasn't much runny yolk to dip my soldiers in.  Maybe that's the price of it all coming in a hot pan to the table, and the egg tends to keep cooking.The big draw card is the view that you get from the restaurant being on the 40th floor of the Heron tower.  As such, it sometimes felt like a tourist attraction and restaurant combined.  It's weird when you have people walking up to the window near your table and taking photos.The service was amiable and we felt welcome.It looks like you need to have a booking whenever you come here. A guy at the bottom of the tower checks your name against a list before you go in the lift. I'm guessing this applies all of the time, even at 4am. (The restaurant is open literally all day.)

OlhG-e5hQPwXhpKSo2Icyg.text: LOVED this place!!! The food, view and elevator ride up is spectacular! Fun fact about this place which surprised the four of us at the table was this place is open 24/7, next time I visit London I will have to come back at night. I don't recall everything that was ordered by us but I had ordered the Carlingford Rock Oysters which were amazing...so fresh and delicious. I also had the signature Duck & Waffle which was amazing, cooked to perfection! Service was excellent as was the whole experience. Next time I'm in London I will definitely come back here at night though!

JXDudZ-XHHSqoV_EdYQRHQ.text: The dress code is highly variable (it gets a little less strict the later you go ) - I tend to be a bit scruffy, so I get turned away about 50% of the time, which I accept is a risk, but it takes an emotional toll that I can't exclude from the review.  The food isn't bad.  It's really nice to have somewhere to go in the early hours of the morning.  I've had some special times here.

MIbNrf4GX4XgtSB58EUPlw.text: It was one of my good friends last nights in London, and we started at a pub near her office. Around the pub's closing time, we were all hungry but at a loss for where to eat until Duck & Waffle dawned us.All four of us ordered the Duck & Waffle (naturally) and no one could have been happier. The Duck & Waffle was perfectly executed and probably in my top 5 favorite meals in London. Such a truly delicious and unique combination. The only slight issue was it was a pretty foggy night and Duck & Waffle wasn't able to lift the clouds.Otherwise, no complaints! Would definitely bring an out-of-towner or anyone celebrating a special occasion.

X8Gkt1bVDza_giYyVbgJ1A.text: The Duck and Waffle is situated on the 40th floor of Heron Tower, right in close proximity to the Liverpool Street Tube Station. On entry to the imposing glass building, my companion and I were greeted by a bouncer with a furry sort of scarf wrapped around his neck, who promptly checked for IDs. We then waited for our turn in the infamous glass lift, which shot up into the sky smoothly--we went in at 11:00 PM, and the city was dotted with dazzling little ants of light. It feels swanky, but not in an uptight and stuffy way. The vibes are young--the way into the actual restaurant is snaky and not-straightforward, and includes walking past an impressive bar display that screams to impress. I know this because I tried very hard to be unimpressed as I stomped by in my heels, and could not stop sneakily glancing at the perfectly placed limes and lemons and shakers and fruits and bottles upon bottles of alcohol.we were seated immediately--the walls are entirely glass and give stunning views of Mthe city. Everyone is drinking. The wine menu and the cocktail menus are both  insane--I saw some 4-digit price tags that made me throw up in the back of my mouth a little bit, and quickly turned to the page with the more reasonably (but oho, dont get too ahead of yourself here, not THAT reasonably) priced 13-14 pound cocktails.The server s were quick, efficient, and friendly. My companion had a Japanese bottled Asahi for 7 pounds, while I pondered throwing away the equivalent of 20 American dollars on a cocktail. It was a no go, I sipped my tap water daintily and pretended it was as glamorous as any ridiculously priced drink.We began with the rosemary garlic bread--amazingly fresh--I could taste the small studs of sea salt--went amazingly with the buttery texture.The duck and waffle was exactly that--crispily roasted duck served atop a half Belgian waffle, served with a tiny little pitcher of maple syrup. Oh, and with a duck egg as well. It was delicious, but there was nothing extraordinary about it. It was well-cooked, but lacked the magic that I expected.My companion had the smoked salmon--this was an amazingly cut, fresh smoked salmon that melted in the mouth, served with slices of flatbread, some watercress salad, and creme fraiche.Overall, the food was excellent. I couldn't shake the vibes that I was finally in one of the 'hip-and-happening' areas of London--the service was meticulous and the views were amazing. Although I gripe about the prices, I knew I was paying for the ambience and the experience, which were truly fantastic.One piece of criticism that I will leave is that the all-day menu should try to be a little more cohesive in its pricing and selection. There are small plates with things like ox cheek and smoked mozzarella and aubergine around 9-10 pounds, and the 'for the table' section served the duck and waffle for 17 pounds and a pearl barley entree for 13 pounds, but then jumps to 30-40 pound entrees like chicken and steak. I would like to see a menu with a few more staples with less of a jump in pricing, and it might bring in an even more enthusiastic clientele than it already has. Excellent experience.
